Tom Cruise entertains in this intriguing sci-fi flick that is full of twists and turns.
Great cast but the script meanders and ends up nowhere.
Not the best of the three but Robert Downey, Jr. is better than ever.
How did they convince Kerry Washington to be in this mess? Talk about a scandal!
McConaughey and Sheridan 's acting skills, as well as those of the entire supporting cast, make this movie better than it ought to be.
The movie is going great until it hangs it all up about 3/4ths of the way through.
The perfect summer/popcorn movie - fast cars, beautiful women, unending action and lots of explosions.
Once again Farrell is better than the material he is given - so is Rapace.
Ashley Bell is still the best thing about the franchise but even she can't rescue this one. No "Part 3" please!
A black mark on the careers of everyone involved in this mess.
A novel take on the Beauty and the Beast story but this time the beast is a zombie.
An okay action movie but sadly Stallone has entered into the "who cares" category.
Bateman and McCarthy elevate the material to a higher level than it should have.
The acting is good and the plot is intense; if you work hard you will find some entertainment.
Willis is still fine but the script and directing make this "a bad day to die hard."
movie_title: A Good Day To Die Hard (2013)

movie_review_blurb: The big stars act silly, and the unknown stars have no spark
This one is pure Nicolas Sparks and for his millions of fans that is more than enough.
An amiable animated feature that should entertain the younger kids.
Dwayne Johnson's gives his best performance yet in this true story of a father's love; "The Rock" is now a name of the past.
A really dumb movie about aliens among us - but the two kid actors are great!
An okay movie for the younger kids but anyone over thirteen will find it amateurish at best.
movie_title: The Lost Medallion: The AdventStoneures of Billy (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Harris, Duchovny and Fichtner lead a strong cast in a engrossing submarine adventure
Another "who wants to see it" fairy tale update. Maybe this is the last nail in the coffin.
"Hangover" for the college crowd, but it's a pale imitation.
Both Franco and the overall aspects of the movie are better than I hoped for or expected.
McConaughey and Leto lost weight in order to show their acting talent in this fact based film.
Delpy and Hawke talk and talk and talk but it is all fascinating.
Same old same old biding time for the finale, but still has Lawrence in the lead and for most that is enough.
This is one of the only times a movie has concerned Wall Street and I understood it.
Fassbender and Vikander light up the screen with their chemistry and talent.
Clint Eastwood + Tom Hanks + Sully = one of the best movies of the year.
Margo Martindale is a national treasure. She has the best comedic moments and the best dramatic ones in this movie.
Washington and Pratt show true grit in this movie, but a lack of character depth makes it entertaining only for those who love violence.
Director Peter Berg makes this film personal enough to get the audience totally aboard. Mark Wahlberg and Kate Hudson lead an almost picture perfect cast.
The new "Ben-Hur" is impressive but not epic. The memory of Charlton Heston in that chariot race still remains
A surprisingly warm and wonderful movie. One of the best of the year!
movie_title: A Man Called Ove (En man som heter Ove) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: In the right role he is great ("Sully"); in the wrong role he is terrible ("Inferno"). This James Bond-ish role in "Inferno" was a wrong fit from the start.

"Hacksaw Ridge" is the best movie I have seen this year. Some will not be able to watch the film because of its intensity and war violence, but for those who can it is an amazing story of faith, courage, love and patriotism.
With a "you fill in the holes" plot, and a must film in the dark mentality, "Arrival" is D. O. A.
Warren Beatty's ego got the best of him in this vanity production. He possibly has out-Ishtarred "Ishtar".
Tries hard to be relevant but falls short, still Lucas Till is an actor who is never boring.
Lewd and crude as well as warm and endearing. But mostly it is just laugh out loud funny.
Some plotholes for sure but the film is surprising and entertaining. Ben Affleck at his best.
Cat lovers young and old will eat it up like catnip.
Shocked by the fun I had with this film. The next one should just be called "Harley Quinn" cause Margot Robbie makes the movie.
Raunchy in the extreme, but the laugh out loud script provides the right balance. Plus the movie has Kathryn Hahn as a secret weapon. She steals the show!
A heart-warming movie based on the true story of Eddie the Eagle Edwards. In the title role Taron Egerton provides a nerdy but irrepressible hero.
Inspirational Entertainment.
"Miracles From Heaven" has a strong cast and an impressive story. It should appeal to a wide audience.
It is aimed squarely at the heart of the Christian base, and for this group it will be manna from Heaven.
The performances of Kevin Costner and Gal Gadot make this a movie worth seeing.
Too much obscene/profane language from the adults and especially from the kids.
The relationships are too forced and the emotional scenes are too cheesy. Still Aniston and Roberts deliver the goods.
The idea of the story is good,; the execution and acting are not. "Papa" would not be pleased.
"Being Charlie" is saved by Nick Robinson's natural and appealing performance in the lead role..
With its sloppy plot, fair to middling acting, and a cheesy look of the seventies "The Nice Guys" is not a nice movie.
This is a dumbed down formulaic comedy that is not deserving of the talent possessed by the two leads.
Based on the popularity of the original, and the strength of the characters created there; this sequel should have been a sure thing. it isn't. Oh it is good but it should have been so much better.
Fans of "The Jungle Book" should enjoy "The Legend of Tarzan". It has the same type of computer generated animals, a dark, dank jungle locale, and Tarzan could be the jungle boy grown to manhood.
Good, solid acting can't overcome a fuzzy script and poor editing.
The steam has run out of the "Ice Age" franchise.
A little slow at the start but overall fresh, funny and full of good music.
Kate Beckinsale is reason enough to go see this movie.
Brett Dalton is the reason to see the film. He manages to combine brashness, cockiness and charm in a winning performance.
The beauty of the locale is the selling point of this movie. Otherwise it is run of the mill.
Gosling and Ford are solid performers but it is Ana de Armas whose star is born.
Takes a true heroic story and does it justice. This is moviemaking as it is supposed to be.
It is funny and touching, full of characters we can all love a little.
The Christmas Story told from a donkey's perspective makes for a fun filled, heart-warming animated movie. Surprisingly good.
It is basically a one man show but when the one man is Denzel Washington at his best, then the movie soars.
A heartfelt story about male friendship. Carell, Fishbourne and especially Cranston are all at the top of their game.
Great acting, great music, good plot. Unlike "La La Land" this movie hits all the right notes.
Everything about this movie is wonder-fu; especially its message..
If this is Daniel Day-Lewis' last film performance he leaves us with a mess.
No passion allowed in this story of seduction and betrayal. This is the sanitized version that can easily be shown in churches.
Chadwick Boseman is the star of the movie but he is fighting a losing battle against scene stealers such as Michael B Jordan, Letitia Wright and Sterling K. Brown.
The story is still compelling but Bruce Willis and Director Eli Roth do not add anything to it. The old cocky, charming Bruce is nowhere in sight.
Slow pacing and a good but not great performance by Jennifer Lawrence detract from the movie, but the twists and turns plus a strong supporting cast lift it up to above average status.
It all plays out in a fast and furious manner. For a good time forget the logic and just go with the flow. It is more fun than you expect it to be.
Affleck is a better director here than actor as witnessed by the performances he gets from Renner and Lively - which outshine his.
A miscast Jennifer Lawrence plus no coherent vision from Aronofsky. An empty shell of a movie.
An amazing cast brings an amazing story to life.
Director Dan Bush gets strong performances from Franco and Eastwood while letting the eerie creepiness of his story shine thru.
Reynolds and Jackson are living proof real talent can elevate the most mundane of material.
Keanu Reeves is at his best when playing a mysterious man of few words. Plus the action scenes are almost believable as he is constantly reloading his weapons.
It is creepily suspenseful and entertaining until those final scenes when it all falls apart.
"The Great Wall" is a movie that should be seen for the visuals it offers, the staging of the battle sequences, and the charm of Matt Damon.
Melanie Lynskey is a younger Margo Martindale. She can play comedy, drama or quirky - and this movie is really quirky.
movie_title: I don't feel at home in this world anymore. (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Well made and well acted; the perfect movie for the Easter season.
A strong plot mixed with dynamic acting added to innovative directing equals a gift of a movie. Mckenna Grace is adorable.
An amazing story and movie that would not be believable if it were not based on true events.
How bad did you think "Snatched" could be? It's worse. And the misuse of Hawn is Goldie abuse.
Still has enough of the Ridley Scott touch to make it above average in entertainment value.
Everything about this new installment seems fresh. Johnny Depp shows once more he was born to play Jack Sparrow.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: Dead Men Tell No Tales (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Loved Gadot. The script and supporting actors/characters not so much.

Edgar Wright picked the perfect actor to play Baby. Ansel Elgort slides into this character like it is a second skin.
Catherine Bell leads a practically perfect cast in this warmly entertaining "Christmas" movie

The lead actors are basically unknown to American audiences and so are easily accepted in their roles. This adds to the overall believability of the film.

Snarky, crude, irreverent - if this is what you are looking for in an action movie then you have some to the right place.

Good acting, great special effects and a perspective that keeps its heart in the right place.

A sloppy movie that glorifies endangering people on our city streets and interstates.
A violent film with an underlayer of comedy - it works for me big time.

Has a decided agenda but still manages to be entertaining
A rarity because this sequel outdoes the original.
A surprisingly good movie about the dangers of life in our country in the mid 1700's.
Keira Knightley sings and so does the movie!
Full of sex, drugs and amoral characters, but it is fascinating to watch.

Good acting but a ludicrous script.

Vince Vaughn fails to deliver the comedy but he does atone somewhat with an emotional finish
Sweet film about Christmas miracles but a little slow at the start - and neither Susan Boyle nor Samantha Barks has a big musical number.
Disney's return to animation greatness, plus that Idina Menzel can really sing.
Just what you expect in a Jason Statham movie - and that is action from beginning to end.
Jennifer Hudson sings like an angel but the movie is not up to that level storywise.
The movie got a big buildup; it then provided a big letdown. Simple fact is the movie is not funny.

A stupid, stupid movie that is not scary and boring to boot!

"Remember the Titans" + "Facing the Giants" + "Rudy" = "Woodlawn"!

Simply beautiful and beautifully simple.

movie_review_blurb: An immensely touching story that is perfectly cast. Much better than expected.

A major disappointment when you consider the talent involved and the resulting blandness of the product.
There are many reasons you should hate "The H8teful Eight" but there are even more reasons to love it.

Exciting and patriotic, it's like John Wayne saving the day one more time.
movie_title: 13 Hours: The Secret Soldiers Of Benghazi (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Not as bad as the trailer makes it look & for a horror film it has a substantial plot.

Finally a sci-fi/thriller that makes you think - and has a logical conclusion.
A small film that stands tall in the field of family entertainment.

movie_review_blurb: What was dumb in the original is dumber in the sequel; what was crude in the original is cruder in the sequel; Galiafinakis was obnoxious in the original and he is more so in the sequel.

It loses points for originality and freshness but it is beautifully animated and the voices are pitch perfect

It is aimed at kids and as far as I could tell it pleased the kid audience - so adults will just have to grin and bear it.
movie_title: Judy Moody and the NOT Bummer Summer (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Let's face it, Woody Allen makes some bad movies or at least only slightly entertaining movies. He might have been great in the past but that day has long gone.

Jim Carrey's warmest, funniest movie in years and its perfect for kids and adults.

The best "comic book" movie I have seen in some time. Good cast, good acting, good special effects - the whole production was first class.

One of the most messed up, confusing movies I have ever struggled through.

Witherspoon has never been more beautiful or dramatic. She and Pattinson create a beautiful love story

As timely as a Tea Party rally, Ayn Rand's novel finally reaches the screen - at least a part of it does.
Sequel number four proves this franchise isn't getting older - it's getting better.
This is a case of a movie not being "bad" enough to be good.
Didn't inform, reform or transform me. It was just a lot of explosions and noise signifying nothing. But for those who like that sort of thing it was perfect.
Definitely for mature audiences as there were no car chases or explosions. Hanks and Roberts still have chemistry together, and there is always that fantastic Roberts laugh.
A throwback to escapist rom com fare in the sixties. Totally unrealistic but still fun for the "tween" set.
The three main characters are gloomy and brooding and that affects the movie. There's too much brooding and not enough fear.
movie_title: Don't Be Afraid Of The Dark (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Paul Rudd is terrific as the loveable, good-hearted, naive Ned. His warmth makes this a feel good film.
There are too many branches on this tree trying to give every unemployed actor in Hollywood a job.

The acting is strong but the story isn't, especially the almost laughable 'let me leave you a note' situation at the end.

An okay cast presents a plot with a few twists but the gruesome ones, especially for a PG-13 rated movie, are totally sadistic
A surprisingly ineffective cast delivers a muddled religious message
The best movie I have seen this year. Hardy, Edgerton and especially Nolte are outstanding!
It seems we have had this plot a million times before and this movie offers nothing new or involving.
All involved will be known as those who took part in the worst movie of the year
movie_title: Bucky Larson: Born to Be a Star (2011)

movie_review_blurb: This well made revenge tale has strong performances all around but James Woods steals the show

After watching Parker giggle and whine her way through this movie the audience won't care how her character does it.
movie_title: I Don't Know How She Does It (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Brad Pitt may be the big draw but it is Jonah Hill's performance that gives the film its flavor. And when they are both on screen the movie is at its best.

A movie about teens with no sex, drugs or alcohol - what an amazing concept!
movie_title: Diary of a Wimpy Kid 2: Rodrick Rules (2011)

movie_review_blurb: The gimmicky one day a year thing makes the movie seem fragmented but the charm of the two leads saves the day.

Should have been more 'Dr. Doolittle' and less 'How to Win a Woman"

Mila Kunis is so adorable and energetic she even manages to make Justin Timberlake likeable, and that is saying a lot.
A fitting farewell for all the zillions of Harry Potter fans; not the best HP movie but one of the best.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows - Part 2 (2011)

movie_review_blurb: The title says it all so if you are okay with that you'll be okay with the movie.
My Smurf name should be Smiley cause I was smiling all the way through this movie.

The special effects, the acting & especially Andy Serkis make this the most believable "Apes" movie yet
movie_title: Rise of the Planet of the Apes (2011)

movie_review_blurb: If you are going to be this gross and crude you had better be awfully funny and this movie isn't.

movie_title: Spy Kids: All the Time in the World in 4D (2011)

movie_review_blurb: When you get that blend of horror and humor right you have a good movie - this is a good movie!

Although directed with technical finesse by newcomer Levan Gabriadze, "Unfriended" starts shrill and only gets louder as it goes along.

Like the mountain for which it's named, "Everest" is rock solid. It's big, it's beautiful, it's terrifying, and it's merciless to both its characters and the audience.
It's infectious - everyone really does look like they're having a great time.
movie_title: Muppet Guys Talking: Secrets Behind the Show the Whole World Watched (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Since the Minions themselves are barely characters, much of the film falls on the shoulders of Bullock. She isn't up to the challenge.
Chappie once again falls short of Blomkamp's debut film, but he still deserves credit for telling an original sci-fi story rooted in real issues.

Dawn of the Planet of the Apes is the kind of summer blockbuster that you want to see. It recognizes that action for the sake of action is not compelling, and that action stemming from brewing conflict and character faults is.
movie_title: Dawn Of The Planet Of The Apes (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Cumberbatch is thrown into the middle of a thriller and given the leeway to show us how the brilliant and troubled Turing works. It's great watching him do just that.
The Theory of Everything is half love story, half biopic, and we never get enough of either.
Everything is here except the thing that matters most, a good director.
Mike Flanagan delivers the high water mark in King Cinema.
It's an exploitation movie that knowingly abuses the male gaze and then turns that uncivilized, leering lens on its head, placing us squarely in the shoes of its brutalized angel of vengeance.
What we're left with is a portrait of the eternal freak, resigned to damnation because he couldn't make friends or lovers out of the young geeks surrounding him, despite his best efforts.
Bodied is a masterwork.
What's still most impressive about Jailbreak is its sense of playfulness.

[Larry] Cohen was one of the unsung Princes of NYC Grime, live-shooting his movies in crowds in order to obtain a Hitchcockian sense of authenticity. His productions were often chaotic and unprepared, but that's what lent them such a vital spark.
movie_title: King Cohen: The Wild World of Filmmaker Larry Cohen (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Tom Cruise's latest is almost subversive in its breezy, anti-US attitude.
Super Dark Times is an unsettling, technically accomplished entry into the recent boom of genre pictures examining losses of innocence through their own unique lenses.
Ethan Hawke is no Keanu Reeves, and 24 Hours to Live is no John Wick, no matter how hard its creative forces are trying to position the picture as the next action cinema classic.
An utter masterwork of illogic.
Sean Baker's latest is a melancholy slice of wonder, viewed through our pint sized protagonist's eyes.

Perhaps the most infuriating element of The Babysitter is that it feels like a horror movie made by someone who doesn't necessarily like horror movies, and is taking this odd opportunity to sort of laugh at the genre.
Thelma is as much a deft character study as it is a pure genre exercise, with Anja evoking desires in this strange girl she barely recognizes beneath her own cold surface.
Cold Hell is exactly what you want from this sort of late night trash cinema hybrid - it's a smash and grab assault on the senses, leaving you out of breath and totally exhilarated.

The Killing of a Sacred Deer will likely prove divisive, as Lanthimos tests the audience's patience with his deliberate pacing, making you feel the same inescapable sense of horror its doomed subjects are suffering through.
movie_title: The Killing of a Sacred Deer (2017)

movie_review_blurb: This attempt at reviving the erotic thriller (not to mention Katherine Heigl's career) is a missed opportunity all around.
So beige and unmemorable that this writer struggled to recall any sort of palpable plot details mere hours after the credits rolled.
Dan Gilroy's NIGHTCRAWLER follow-up is an odd mixed bag with a fascinating central performance.
T2 is not only a great film in its own right, but a perfect continuation of a classic that more than likely didn't need to be expanded upon.

Prevenge proves that the actress-cum-filmmaker has a sense of cringe comedy that's distinctly her own, and it'll be grand watching a woman continue to bring her own brand of cruel genre toys to a table usually reserved by boys.
Win it All is Swanberg's tightest movie, and no doubt his most accessible; the directing/writing/performing duo having discovered a true rhythm and shorthand together that's magic when it works.
There are moments when the seams and their relative inexperience show but, for the most part, The Strange Ones is a wholly engrossing work of palpable anxiety.
Thanks to a solid dosage of weirdness, BAYWATCH is more watchable than you might expect.
Funny enough to forgive its rote detours, slinging crass goofiness at the audience's face like a stripper swings his banana hammock in a dubstep blaring Miami strip club.
Koontz's feature debut is a sturdy, adult scare picture, which is a treat unto itself.
Salma Hayek gives the best performance of '17 (thus far) in this dark comedy of manners.
Kathryn Bigelow and Mark Boal return with a ferociously angry social horror movie.
The Hitman's Bodyguard acts as the cinematic mimosa you down after a night of tequila, some $3 hair of the dog Cook's and OJ that eases you into the next day without too much hassle.
Not without problems, but also not as bad as you've heard.
A poorly conceived film that is interesting enough to be entertaining, but certainly not good enough for a recommendation.
A neorealist take on Hasidic life that is fascinating, if slightly repetitive.
Another standout performance from Lakeith Stanfield.
Wheelman is a movie slightly at war with itself. It's an anti-action picture that still attempts to commit to the genre trappings it's visually toying with.
Three Billboards Outside Ebbing, Missouri is a funny, shocking, oddly sobering reminder that people should inform the process, not the other way around.

[Harry Dean Stanton is] one of the great ones; perhaps even the great one in terms of certain naturalistic affectations. And Lucky is here to act as a Greatest Hits record of sorts, bringing closure to a career that's worth celebrating.

If this all sounds preposterous, it's because it totally is. But Banderas brings such a fiery commitment to the role that we buy into Florentine's world of cleanly choreographed battles and the Russian tough guys who engage in them.
An aimless two hours where it takes forever for the central mystery to unravel and, by the time it does, you don't really care at all about the "big reveal".
An ice cold procedural, where bodies become little more than tools for the state, in a flesh for secrets game that leaves everyone who plays physically and spiritually damaged.
This year's Estonian submission for the Best Foreign Language Oscar is gorgeous, but somewhat impenetrable for the unfamiliar.

Containing laughably high levels of violence, sex and sadism that become near numbing by the final reel, Eaten Alive! is possibly the cruelest, most tasteless entry into a collection already known for being utterly reprehensible.
There's a reason this film's appearance on MST3K lead to one of the famed series' best episodes: there's just so much fodder for filmic abuse that one can't help but crack wise while viewing it.
A solid tale, told pretty damn well.

For all the monster movie madness, cheap thrills and wonderful filmic texture, this is still very much a motion picture about the terrors of parenthood, and how the best mothers and fathers would do anything to keep their kids safe.
Wildling is most certainly a horror movie, essentially playing like a straight-faced, female-fronted Teen Wolf reboot.
Ready Player One is one of the most egregiously set piece-driven slices of pop cinema we've seen in a long while.
A frightful ninety-minute diversion that packs four British horror pictures into one.

Ali & Cavett will more than likely be forgotten by many who view it, as Bader and Cavett do very little to try and brand what's already an incredible human interest story on the brains of audience members.
movie_title: Ali & Cavett: The Tale of the Tapes (2018)

movie_review_blurb: Had Prospect zeroed in on this dynamic a little more, it would probably play a little better than the glorified directors' reel the picture truly is.

Sadly, the movie is never able to rid itself of a somewhat somnambulant aura, as these wayward bottom feeders hope to find a better life, and we know that nothing but pain and sadness await in their future.

For Leigh and Cam, we may never hear them use quirky nicknames, but they most certainly exist, because their relationship lets us - absolute strangers - take a peek inside their souls when they think nobody's really looking.
It's unafraid to indulge in cinema's ability to create these fantastical scenarios.
The director of EX MACHINA returns, delivering a thrilling, gorgeous bit of big studio pulp filmmaking.
It's just all so sad, but never actually rings true, a movie about grace in defeat that showcases few discernible grace notes.
Lough has crafted something terrifying and vital: a document of discontent that promises things are only going to get worse before they can get better.

While definitely still a treat for fans of the martial arts star and his new English partner in crime, Accident Man is also a mild disappointment, mostly because the film seemingly bit off a touch more than it could chew.

As fun as Creepshow is, the movie Romero and King crafted is also an act of revenge, as each has recounted in interviews how the EC titles the movie is paying tribute to were frowned upon by many in mainstream society.

There's an ample amount of blunt brutality on display, and a solid twist on who the killer turns out to be, marking The Severed Arm as a rather intriguing deep cut when discussing the beginnings of horror's more prolific subcategorizations.
Harmon gets to indulge her more hallucinatory tendencies through director Frank Roach.
For a cheap cash-in (which this no doubt is), there's still a solid amount going on under Graduation Day's hood, even as the bodies begin to pile toward the ceiling.
The DC machine has finally manufactured a product that actually tastes pretty good, even if still feels like a copy overall.

The bastard offspring of an entire drive-in era, Night of the Comet is one of the most unique motion pictures from any age, and it's a wonder that more modern filmmakers haven't used it as a cinematic template.
Franco transforms Sestero's BTS memoir into a genuinely touching tale of two outsiders.
Jamie Dagg's overcast neo noir is a sturdy, somber slice of violent pulp.
Hugh Jackman's big top musical isn't the disaster you've heard it is...but it also isn't good.
All the Money In the World is much more American Gangster ('07) than it is Hannibal ('01) - the opulence of its subjects' lavish lifestyles somewhat muted by an oppressive blue color palette.
movie_title: All the Money in the World (2017)

movie_review_blurb: That's possibly Automatic At Sea's finest quality: a delightful ambiguity toward not only its subjects, but the very thesis of the film, as well.
A real movie that never forgets that it's still playing to a crowd desperately seeking cheap thrills.
Chris Hemsworth's post-9/11 horse soldier actioner is a bland attempt at revitalizing a producer's brand.
Robert Mockler's directorial debut is a New Media scorcher.
Granted, there may be some problematic road traversed in regards to mental health issues and power dynamics, but the talent involved is too great to deny Aardvark at least one viewing.
Sam Patton's creepy camping picture boils genre down to its essence.
Miss Sloane plays out like a very long episode of a very boring TV drama.

Blending body positivity with its thinly (ha!) veiled race allegory in the streets, taking protest signs and squaring off with demonstrators until the police show up, the cast of Hairspray Live! gave us a musical nudge to action.
The limited pop culture references and focus on its talented supporting players give Why Him? a charm that doesn't bury its insight.
It's certainly more entertaining than it has a right to be, but its milquetoast weirdness never goes full throttle.
Don't think it, don't say it, don't see it.
Dig Two Graves is a bizarre film that builds up strange-but-muddled imagery like better films build suspense, until it all collapses in on itself like a burning house.
The film's aesthetic is its unassailable strength. Despite a somewhat muddy plot of oscillating energies, it always looks like the kind of thing Hot Topic wishes it could dream up.
When not focusing on Burke's sad stand-up, we shift to his creepy personal life. It's a depressing double-edged sword, yet the tone never wavers.
The Ottoman Lieutenant is a war romance wherein the romance isn't made more complex by the war, nor is the war made more complex by the romance.

Despite some convoluted final action ... and unbalanced music, Beauty and the Beast's teary fairy tale ending survives it all thanks to the brief but colorful relationships we develop with the side characters.
Director Craig Johnson's film isn't sharp enough to balance out how unpalatable it is.
The creatively scary film's purposefully misleading ending is fun in a cruel kind of way, especially coming from a horror that's already put us through so much. Alas, such is Life.
Pitt, wonderful here, thrives in films that don't ask for a mugging, simple punchline... Meanwhile, Cotillard dominates the film as both subject and object.

Railroad Tigers is an old-school, moderately campy adventure movie, something American directors were focused on making in the '90s (think 1995's Jumanji) but audiences have mostly relegated today to the realm of nostalgia.
Don't let the goatee fool you - this is no Iron Man.
Nothing in the rulebook says dog movies can't be boring.
It's heartfelt and beautiful in its simplicity, ending with a series of perfect moments that will cement it as a true Disney classic.
The overfull inbox of business jokes falls spectacularly flat when viewed in our current national climate, and seem completely insane in a movie for children.
Eddie isn't groundbreaking by any means, but effortlessly fun, packed with irony, and ready to woo even the most unathletic children through countless TV reruns.
Simultaneously a vibrant, colorful love letter to the unsung parts of Los Angeles, a populist philosophy of food and culture, and a thesis on what criticism should be.
[It] has all of the makings of drama and none of the chops. That's what most of this film feels like: empty wind through a trumpet - no tone, just air.
In what plays like a modern take on The Godfather, queer sexual politics and Mexican machismo rasp upon each other, filing the young criminals at its heart into husks.
movie_title: I Promise You Anarchy (Te prometo anarquía) (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Acid drips from every line and visual gags double as celebrity commentary while still delivering sublime slapstick.
If we're Dante, Tom Hanks is Virgil and Inferno is Hell.
Its two hours become overwrought with cutesy flashes that flit along the edges of the honest, hardscrabble tales Steiner has unearthed.
Sadly, much of this is underserved by a script equally overplotted and underwritten.
The rare documentary both vague enough to whet your appetite and specific enough to imbue a sense of kinship with its subject, like an old friend from camp you haven't seen in decades.
Phantom of the Paradise is not just one of the flashiest, angriest musical films, but an enduring and damning kiss-off to America's spiraling desperation for entertainment.
A promising cast is hamstrung by its emotionless premise.
Neither Heaven Nor Earth finds beauty and horror in its thematic explorations of the culture clash where civilization meets war, its polar foe.
movie_title: Neither Heaven nor Earth (Ni le ciel ni la terre) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Pure millennial schlock, Nerve is a lot of dumb fun.
The shorts all play like exceedingly surreal commercials, like Mentos ads on crack.
movie_title: Rio, I Love You (Rio, Eu Te Amo) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Gifted is saddest when we realize, as it takes grueling and meandering scenic routes through tearjerker clichés, the pregnant potential for this to be a sharp family dramedy.

An irreverent mix of genres taken completely seriously but with no small amount of fun, Devil's Gate wears its script's stupidity on its sleeve and allows its creature effects and committed cast to carry it throughout.
Though beautifully shot by Eli Born as '90s ultra-Americana, Super Dark Times never seems sure which way to make us look. Which isn't a good thing.

The NYC realism highlighting the abuse young queer people can face is often so tough as to break your heart. It's a stunning debut from writer/director Damon Cardasis and an even more impressive showcase for star Luka Kain's musical and dramatic talents.
The film has a nuanced faith offset by brutal fight scenes and lingering, all-encompassing nature photography.
A great young cast, steady pacing, and dusty aesthetic unafraid to show the drug trade in all its unflattering practicalities make Thumper a must-see thriller.
The film is remarkable for its willingness and ability to flaunt its generic premise and go to far stranger, more empowering places than its simple setup might suggest.
Deidra & Laney Rob a Train is both a caper film and a high school comedy and for every moment it stumbles at one, it excels at the other.
Inevitably, more time will be spent mulling over the title of Brad's Status than the film itself.

Rebel in the Rye's script problems aren't just its broad issues of scope which leave little room for directorial creativity. The minutiae of the film's scenes are undermined by a screenplay with details so sparse.
Patti Cake$ clearly loves music, but fails to translate that into a compelling narrative. It's an album filled mostly with half-baked skits.
Step may stumble over its own hurried pace but such a method is almost forgivable once you realize that the film is speeding towards an effective finale.
The very core of this kind of teen summer schlock, Wish Upon will only be remembered as a laughable neighbor to the Wishmaster series.

While the film can sometimes feel sparse, the combination of this defiant juxtaposition, its diligently-defined historical context and some perfectly-pitched nastiness cast The Little Hours into the midnight movie heavens.

Captain Underpants' plethora of animation styles (including a wonderful sock puppet sequence) separates the film into imaginative sublayers, keeping it from feeling like the one-joke wonder that it often edges towards.
movie_title: Captain Underpants: The First Epic Movie (Captain Underpants) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Win It All is a slow-burn dramedy set on undercutting the romanticized, disheveled losers of noir while still developing a charm of its own.
Community activism is charged by action, otherwise it'd be community passivity, but Copwatch does best when going back to the source of activism's power.
Named like a horror movie but packaged like a rom-com, The Boy Downstairs is a sweet showcase of writer/director Sophie Brooks' takes on memory, expectation and charm.
Leveaux's is a romantic and pleasantly small film about love in an era when love always contested with duty to something greater.

The film is intense, making for one of the sniffliest audiences in which I've ever been included, so viewer discretion is certainly advised. But with that kind of emotional power too comes the intellectual and statistical weight we need to enact change.

[It] is pure investigative journalism. It trusts no one and questions every side of the story -- even the possible coercion of illegal activities by one of its stars while those he coerced have threatened to shoot him in the head if he ever turns up again
The film-directed and written by Mickey Keating, regent of horror references-cobbles its many genre touchstones into a winding walkway to absolutely nowhere.

The Last Poker Game is an unexpectedly warm movie, shot with a honed sense of visual storytelling-especially given the director's newness with all this-and an eye for textures, but one which flames out into a terribly overwrought ending.
There are two movies here, and the actors handle that duality well. But the brooding darkness lurking inside these characters needs a drama of its own.
The Sensitives sees its skeptics coming and bulldozes forward.
The film understands the importance of appearances and loyalties in a person's life. These commitments-either to popes, kings, or gods-are built on faith and risk.
It's all wrapped in a package wearing dad jeans: too safe, too simple, too given to a happy ending.
Thumper is a heart-in-throat drama wherein you know what will happen, and it's all the more dreadful for it.
We linger on dread throughout Sweet Virginia, externalizing a movie whose strengths are all internal.
Dog Years' lack of faith in its audience makes its over-explanation and hackneyed groaners unshakable weights on a story that only needed to let Reynolds do his thing.
The Clapper is just so boring and corny that all the audience can do is either feel bad for Helms or disingenuously applaud his unsuccessful efforts, mimicking his character's chosen vocation.
The film's ridiculousness deserves a long hill to snowball down-when Rock'n Roll reaches the bottom, it's impossible not to be bowled over.
Saturday Church is a racially and sexually diverse rumination on identity that defies simple definition in its low-key elegance.
The politics of piracy are complex and well-explored here.

Capably shot, well acted (notwithstanding Kate Winslet's shape-shifting accent), its score propulsive, if a little too insistent, it's a finely crafted piece of work. But as a film, I found it nearly insufferable.

Niki Caro breaks out of the genre and emerges with a truly moving and original film. She uses the familiar structure of survival and rescue, but her focus is on the mechanics of cruelty itself in an unlikely setting.
Sollima displays a knack for refining material and balancing plotlines that would seem overbearing in lesser hands.
With utmost care applied to its every shot, the adults will be marvelling as much as the youngsters.
Wingard's inclusion of subgenres (a dash of Cronenberg body horror; a smattering of sci-fi) steers the film in an unexpectedly bold new direction, justifying its existence on its own merit.
It may be watchable fare boosted by two dedicated performances worthy of discussion, yet this sports biopic - unlike the showdown it builds towards - fails to feel like one for the ages.
Call off the search -- the summer's first show-stopper is here.
movie_title: War for the Planet of the Apes (2017)

movie_review_blurb: A disjointed biopic that frustratingly settles for pleasing the crowds rather than wowing them.
While this outing is often an enjoyable, pulse-quickening spectacle that should be seen on the biggest screen you can find, the franchise's peak -- fifth film Fast Five -- just won't be bettered.
With few tricks up its sleeve, Sharknado only adds to the list of hysterical Syfy monster-dramas that make for a shamelessly brainless 90 minutes well-spent.
Although director Chuck Russell captures a rich textured look and lays on the ghoulish special effects, Bless the Child doesn't generate any real chill.
Patel's constant anger and destitution get a bit tedious, but the uplifting ending will move even the most stoic movie-goer to tears.
An intimate tale that will leave you deeply affected [and] one of the best films of 2016.
With great casting and a stellar performance by Andre Royo, Hunter Gatherer is a film that questions and celebrates the eternal optimist.

If you are going into The Magnificent Seven expecting a cinematic masterpiece...you will be severely disappointed. But if you want two hours of laughs, bullets, brawls, and perhaps a few tears, [it's] a serviceable distraction.
Instead of what was promised, we must struggle through...a bad 90's romantic comedy masquerading as a comic book movie.
HARDCORE HENRY is like watching the world's best FPS video game directed by Sam Raimi, scored by the Sex Pistols, while on acid in the midst of an earthquake.
Garance Miller sells every [cannibalistic] bite with cringing authenticity.
[Split] is a solid thriller highlighted by a career-defining performance from McAvoy.
Paul Verhoeven returns to European cinema, with French cinematic icon Isabelle Huppert, and gives us modern-day psychological crime thriller that is as dark as it is brilliant.
An Old-Fashioned shoot-em/Farce that is quintessentially British. Featuring a hilarious cast of characters Free Fire is; a short plot, long on laughs, frenetic, yet entertaining genre film.
Hugh Jackman has been Wolverine for over 17 years, and yet he found a way to deliver a [new] version of the character...in quite possibly the best performance of his career.
The love story is messy, complicated, yet unconsciously romantic.
Chon's black-and-white indie throwback is cinematic, emotional, and authentic-yet undeniably problematic.
The path to hell is paved with the best intentions, and the first stop is Suburbicon.

Roxanne Roxanne is a story that needed to be told, And if you are familiar with the story you will likely to find it bold, but it needs just a bit more guidance and perhaps more time, to truly let the story of this forgotten star shine.
Keanu is chuckle-out-loud-funny for the majority of the film. Key and Peele come hard with their first big screen story. Keanu is funny and fresh, if slightly formulaic, buddy action comedy.
Even with stumbles, the film was a fun ride, and Heigl's crazy-ex foolery is well worth the price of admission.
As depressing as it is to listen to children who can't play because of their weight, there is much to be hopeful about.
Danny Says' technical shortcomings get a pass because the subject matter is so fascinating that these details can be overlooked.
If I hadn't committed to writing a review of Is That A Gun In Your Pocket?, I likely wouldn't have had to convince myself to sit through the second half of it.
movie_title: Is That a Gun in Your Pocket? (2016)

movie_review_blurb: The Family Fang is an enjoyable film to watch with genuine characters who have relatable flaws and believable bonds.
You may have to be at just the right stage in your life to appreciate it - but for those of us who are there, The Intervention is a great film.
After watching Love Between The Covers and getting to know some of these authors, I'm now interested in picking up a few of their books myself.
California High carefully presents both sides of the argument (pro and anti weed legalization), yet lacks some depth.
Mark of the Witch feels like one long visually enticing nightmare that makes about as much sense as a bad dream in an alternate reality.
London Town is a mostly entertaining romp and its cute fantasy is what makes it work.
Here Alone is definitely not the worst zombie movie I've ever seen, but I won't be recommending it to any of my zombie enthusiast friends either.
The Wedding Invitation is a romantic comedy with a little bit of raunchy humor, done well with strong female characters.
Hearing Is Believing is a modern day version of the American Dream; not everyone has lost faith in it and some still believe it's worth pursuing, obstacles and all.
I Am Heath Ledger is shrouded with the tone of a eulogy, but serves as a tribute to Ledger's short life and accomplishments compiled by his loved ones, for his fans.

In a writing and directorial debut from Matt Jacobs, who co-directed with Liz Graham, Eve Annenberg gives a five-star performance for her portrayal of Woman in Wedding Dress in the quirky late night adventure story, From Hollywood to Rose.
The concept is unoriginal and uninspired but Ripped does have several laugh out loud moments brought on by a talented cast.
Turn It Around is a nostalgia piece for those who lived it, a film for the fans to enjoy and a tribute to the man who set it all in motion.
movie_title: Turn It Around: The Story of East Bay Punk (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Sidemen is well-rounded, with a captivating story which is accompanied by sharp picture and the authentic sound of good ol' blues jams throughout the film.
Second Nature is a feel good goofy comedy that takes a poke at gender roles and has a fun cast of characters running the show.
The Atoning is unoriginal and underwhelming at every turn. Even the climatic moments are anti-climatic.

Plays out like blasting your coolest friend's record collection in your car at 100 mph on the Atlanta freeway while cops close in on all sides - essentially what happens in the movie again and again, to always-riveting effect.
It may soon join Tim Burton's Ed Wood in the ranks of great movies about terrible movies.
[Professor] Marston [& the Wonder Women] is simply a love letter to the amazing people who inhabit it.

This movie is the act of someone who thinks he's getting ahead of the story, who believes he can make something that almost smacks of being an admission and still take a $5 million distribution deal with the Orchard
You'll probably walk away from Super Size Me 2: Holy Chicken! shivering with disgust and wondering how you can go on living in a world as gross and inhumane as ours.
I sat on the edge of my seat, clapping with delight every few minutes.
Luckily, the Louis Theroux-led flick takes a unique direction and completely shatters our expectations.

Combining archival footage, interviews, and stunning VFX recreations, the film chronicles the hard work of the men who worked in Mission Control, the lives of astronauts they sent to space, and their efforts to save the crew of Apollo 13.
movie_title: Mission Control: The Unsung Heroes of Apollo (2016)

movie_review_blurb: The unfortunate fact is, however, that the short takes itself too seriously to ever be truly moving.
Small Crimes is a fascinating character.
The manner in which things unfold, however, is mildly baffling, and loses sight of the original intention. Casting JonBenét is not just unusual; it's straight-up weird.
The fresh, genuinely funny rom-com will make you feel a lot of things, and you'll undoubtedly emerge wishing that Williams was your best friend.
[Robert] De Niro's interpretation of this greed-driven, grandiose villain is not sympathetic; it's intimate and unforgiving, and makes Madoff a more frustrating figure than ever.
Buried deep beneath all the booze and bullets, there is some humanity here - it just takes a little digging to unearth it all.

If you enter this film with the optimism that perhaps it's going to change your perspective on rats, like many other animal-based documentaries have, you will unfortunately be very, very disappointed.
If anything, The Newspaperman is a reminder that we all might benefit from boasting the same determination to expose lies that Bradlee did.
movie_title: The Newspaperman: The Life and Times of Ben Bradlee (2017)

movie_review_blurb: While certainly set up to be a home run with its cast and director, the film never really finds its own voice.
movie_title: The Most Hated Woman In America (2017)

movie_review_blurb: If any of the Child's Play installments before this one made you question the franchise, Cult of Chucky will restore your faith in this deranged doll and all his unhinged antics.
If you're tired of formulaic horror that leaves little to the imagination, It Comes at Night is the perfect remedy.
Just like men have been given the chance to tell a wide range of stories, women shouldn't be confined to one kind of narrative - and in XX, they aren't. That's what makes it so skin-crawlingly fun.
Newtown succeeds because of the powerful emotional story it tells; while it is incredibly gut-wrenching, it leaves viewers with a message of hope and unity, and a vital call to action.
What's marvelous about director-screenwriter Shane Black's depiction of the holiday season is that he captures it in a way that feels true to life (no matter how absurd the circumstances).
Wright understands how to perfectly balance action, comedy, drama, and suspense, and it pays off.
...could have shaken things up with a tighter script and better execution, but instead, it winds up being both tired and tedious, two sins no horror movie can survive.
... it's breathtaking, totally necessary viewing.
... it maintains a sense of self-awareness and depth that sets it apart from many of its genre counterparts.
It's an ambitious, expansive project, and it's clear that Weiwei has poured his heart and soul into it so that we can see the hearts and souls of the millions affected by this devastation.
Watching a guy try to get out of the friend zone by any means possible for 90 minutes is not really my idea of a fun rom-com, but it does make for a pretty chilling thriller.
This little movie's got a lot of heart, and it's a heart that's unafraid to embrace life's littlest moments in all its forms.
... there's no doubt that you'll have a lot to think about by the time What the Health's credits roll.
Newtown succeeds because of the powerful emotional story it tells; while it is incredibly gut-wrenching, it leaves viewers with a message of hope and unity, and a vital call to action.
... one of best scare-fests of the last year ...
Signs manages to be creepy, emotional, and thrilling all at once.
Buffy the Vampire Slayer evidently exists to show us what a rough, rough draft looks like...
... a rare, unmissable gem; yes, it's a showcase for its stunning performers and necessary story, but it also pushes us to look at our own emotions, experiences, and relationships in the process ...
The Village is a truly special film, one that is largely misunderstood by the masses.
