As passably entertaining as the film is, it never surrenders to the abandon of its action and as such never feels like it shifts out of first gear.
With Arrival, Denis Villeneuve communicates the wonder of a Steven Spielberg alien movie within a decidedly hard sci-fi milieu.
The acting elevates the clichés of Barry Jenkins's script into something approaching lived truth.
The final act is one of the strongest sustained sequences of cinema Werner Herzog has crafted in some time.
Voyage of Time acknowledges that Terrence Malick's fussy editing can only suggest meanings to that which will outlive anyone's interpretation.
The film rises above the mawkishness or dreary didacticism that characterize too many of its peers.
The film should have been a cautionary tale, but in Peter Berg's hands, it's a hollow account of the resilience of the human spirit.
Nothing that Marvel Studios has produced can compare to the visual splendor of Scott Derrickson's Doctor Strange.
"The Hunter" doesn't particularly test him, but Dafoe, who's in every scene of the film, easily dominates it.

Perhaps Liebesman, whose previous movie was the grim "Battle: Los Angeles," is too drawn to the spectacle of battle to find the balance of camp and seriousness a patently ludicrous film such as "Wrath of Titans" seeks.
After breaking apart the crime film, McDonagh puts it back together again for a conclusion worthy of the genre.
Cavalierly conceived, generically titled and derivatively plotted. It feels like a missed chance because Pearce and Grace came ready to play.
With limitless absurdity comes a kind of glossy-eyed meaninglessness and extreme tastelessness.
movie_title: Tim and Eric's Billion Dollar Movie (2012)

movie_review_blurb: "The Raid: Redemption" will offer a full meal to action-starved moviegoers, but strike most others as -- for all its athletic dynamism -- lacking nutrition.

It ... feels utterly neutered, a film with little on the line and a talented cast begging for a little wit and a few jokes. The characters are introduced awkwardly and a strange insertion of an animated dream sequence is entirely out of place.
It's Shannon who doesn't just steal the film, he towers over it.
Too shiny and drenched in California glow to feel very personal. It grows increasingly sentimental, and by the end, lays it on especially thick.

As artificial as much of the apparatus surrounding Perry may be, none of it works without her charisma at the center. That comes through in "Part of Me," as does her intense drive to succeed after early failures.
The filmmakers stuff the film to a manic degree, albeit with increasingly textured animation.
Though many of the jokes land, some of them feel like a game of penis-related Mad Libs.
An increasingly incredulously plotted series of embarrassments about the wounded masculinity of a low sperm count.
ParaNorman, blessed with otherworldly animation, can't escape the demons of story.
Just barely a movie, "Act of Valor" is more like a high-quality recruitment video with interstitial acting.
Throughout, there's a tension of real life and fiction, and a pervading sense that fiction has little chance of matching the real thing.
Instead of leading toward understanding, "Rampart" remains a dirty cop caricature, more a complaint than a story.
Any enterprise like this is inherently self-congratulatory, but the film is best considered from Crowe's perspective: that of a fan.
Ultimately, the film feels less like a genuine existential thriller than a movie aping the conventions of one.
Today's terrorism paranoia, apparently, is too complex and too faceless for some. No, we need a clear-cut enemy. Do you have something in red?
Director Gavin O'Connor has turned the octagon of Ultimate Fighting into a cage of boiling family emotion.
The material isn't up to Van Sant's abilities, and the impression of "Restless" is of a filmmaker playing with familiar themes and searching for an adequate vessel.

As an action star, Lautner handles himself reasonably well. He has a bit too much of a boy-band singer look to him, but he's likeable and the major deficiency of "Abduction" isn't his. It's the script.
"Margaret" remains tantalizingly unfulfilled.
Wormald and Hough are both handsome and good on the dance floor, but they come across more like teen stars in training than representations of real youth angst.
A beautifully stylized film.
Robinson, who also wrote the screenplay adaptation, doesn't present the cartoonish Thompson we've come to expect. It's a refreshing, grounded view of the writer.
The resonating images of Hoover are of a man increasingly and tragically out of step with time. Thankfully, it's been quite the opposite for Eastwood.
Comedy moved on from the mid-1990s, and it's time Sandler did, too. "Jack and Jill" even gives fart jokes a bad name.

"The Artist" is propelled by its performances, particularly Dujardin's. He has an exquisite elegance, and builds a whole movie with only his gestures. It's impossible to imagine "The Artist" without him, the wellspring of its charm.
The play has been significantly but artfully trimmed by John Logan's screenplay, which preserves Shakespeare's language.
If there is some kind of world record for schmaltz, this may have set it.
Puns like these would be unforgivable coming from a human. From high-pitched rodents, they prompt calls for an exterminator.
There isn't enough context given to the overall conflict, and the love story feels increasingly myopic as the war drags on and the film's ambitions broaden.
movie_title: In the Land of Blood and Honey (2011)

movie_review_blurb: This thoroughly well-crafted, if rigidly conceived film could use a little more talking -- at least some therapy! -- about Kevin.
movie_title: We Need to Talk About Kevin (2012)

movie_review_blurb: The biggest flaw here is the corny script by John Ridley and Aaron McGruder, the Boondocks cartoonist. There's a fine, swaggering vibe, but a curious hesitance to really tell the Tuskegee story.
The appeal of a good ol' ghost story is strong, and the simplicity of "The Woman in Black" suits the tradition.
In the end, ''On the Road'' remains paved over.
Not just a positively charming movie, but an ode to the tactile pleasures of handcrafted artistry.
"Stoker" certainly relies too much on its heavy Gothic atmosphere, but it does add up to something - particularly because of Wasikowska's deft performance.
Perhaps at this point, even diehards may wish for something more from a Marvel equation that often subtracts humanity.

The exaggerated world of The Hunger Games... would overwhelm most young actors. But Lawrence (convincingly tormented in this film) has a calm sincerity and steely determinism that cuts through it all.
''Out of the Furnace'' is an earnestly crafted, passionately acted working-class drama rusted over by its noble intentions of steel-town sympathizing.
Just as Travers is eventually won over by her Hollywood adversaries, the strong sentimental pull of ''Saving Mr. Banks'' overwhelms, too.
Branagh endows his film with (mostly) old-fashioned competency - something often lacking in today's action films - but little to distinguish it from superior thrillers that have come before.
The film - an ode to craftsmanship - establishes without a doubt that many of the traits we reserve for other fields - dedication, ingenuity - are also inherent to the artistic process. Ta-da.
''The Monuments Men'' is ... weighed down by dutifulness. It feels like it's only a third act, lacking any buildup of tension or character development.
Vallee directs ''Dallas Buyers Club'' with a loose naturalism, seedy environs and lively humor that prevents the film from becoming over-sentimentalized.
This ''RoboCop'' has updated the dystopia with some clever ideas and better acting, while at the same time sanitizing any satire with video-game polish and sequel baiting.
As with so many high-concept films, it takes an awful lot of implausibility to keep the story airborne.
It's as if Douglas Sirk made a combat video game.

Gregory and Huyck don't go far in exploring the weirdness and emotional difficulty that a group of lifelong friends might create in sleeping together -- they want so much for a carefree holiday from such concerns.
"Muppets Most Wanted" fails to whip up the kind of furry frenzy that makes the Muppets special.

While ''The Winter Soldier'' succeeds as finely engineered merchandise built to be crowd-pleasing entertainment, for moviegoers and shareholder alike, it has a shelf life that won't last much past its running time.
"Transcendence" is clunky and lifeless. It's like the movie version of a paranoid TED talk.
Cassavetes seemingly tries to sap any energy that Mann and Diaz give the film. Any time music kicks in, terrible filmmaking results, usually in montage form.
An irresistibly entertaining documentary that captures Stritch during what she unsentimentally calls ''almost post-time.''
The feeling of doom, whether personal or planetary, is today pervasive. But All Is Lost, in the end, is a stirring, repudiation of its own title.
Pretty on the outside but lacking something more than a menagerie of lush brunette heads.
''Don Jon'' is a lark, but an enjoyable one with a full-hearted finale, and it further reveals the considerable talents of Gordon-Levitt.
The screenplay by J. H. Wyman is squirm-inducing in its preposterous dialogue and haphazard plotting.
"The Call" dials up a shallow thrill ride, but one efficiently peppered with your typical "don't go in there!" moments.
Even when "The Sapphires" is at its most unpolished and cheesiest, O'Dowd and the film's general warm spirit make it a tune hard to resist.
For those who enjoy the simple thrill of handsomely stylized image-making, ''Oblivion'' is mostly mesmerizing.
The film hasn't quite earned the grim resonance it seeks.
The heavy metal action could never sink the irrepressible Downey, but it weighs down the otherwise light joy of ''Iron Man 3.''
Moviegoers will likely have few better options this summer for a good romantic comedy.
The gravity that cloaks ''Man of Steel'' is merely an en vogue costume.
Pixar's ''Monsters University'' might not be as gifted as some of its other movies, but sometimes it's alright to be OK.
If stripped of its production value, ''White House Down'' would make one hysterical off-Broadway one-act.
There's a limit, it turns out, to how much Johnny Depp and a bucket of makeup can accomplish.
For a movie about an unjust death, "Fruitvale Station" is bursting with the colorful, messy striving of life.
The Conjuring is an unusually sturdy piece of haunted-house genre filmmaking.
When the end-credit bloopers roll, Sudeikis and Aniston, free of the contrived plot, look like they're finally having fun.
It desperately gathers clichés like a teen fantasy Frankenstein that doesn't realize its secret identity: parody.
movie_title: The Mortal Instruments: City of Bones (2013)

movie_review_blurb: The action (all at nighttime) is messily and crudely filmed. The plot mechanics are often laughable.
It's not only one of the better racing films, it's one of Howard's best.
A kind of "Training Day" hoping for interstitial Terrence Malick poetry in the Baltimore landscape of "The Wire" with the occasional sensationalism of an action film.
July, with her Chaplin eyes, perhaps knows too well how to play earnest and smart. But "The Future" feels progressively less adorned, even as it grows more magical.
No animals may have been hurt in this production, but Brendan Fraser was.
Gluck is clearly whip smart and he likes his films that way. This all to the good, but much of "Friends with Benefits" comes off as too showy in its cleverness.
For too much of the 2 1/2-hour 2012, the end is not near.
There's not another filmmaker working today (or perhaps ever) who believes so strongly in the extremes of melodrama.
Cage dives headlong into the madness. It's plain fun to see the actor give himself so fully to a character after several years of mostly forgettable action movies.
movie_title: Bad Lieutenant: Port of Call New Orleans (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Adapting a masterpiece such as The Road is a thankless task, but the film doesn't work on its own merits.
The aspiration of Brothers is noble. But it can't preserve the intimacy of the original film, and the loosened characters slide into cliche.
The message is clear, if you didn't get it from the rich acting: This is a film to celebrate nature and life.
Invictus is dripping with inspiration -- how to summon it, how to communicate it. Late in his career, Eastwood seems to be finding it everywhere.
Too much of the film is geared around 3-D wizardry. Unneeded sequences pop up for purely "wow" baiting.
A movie whose effects are clearly revolutionary, a spectacle that millions will find adventure in. But it nevertheless feels unsatisfying and somehow lacks the pulse of a truly alive film.
Areta's film has whimsy and a few great lines, but not enough originality.
Though it's dated, the larger issue has to do with those timeless problems of plot and character.
movie_title: The Loss of a Teardrop Diamond (2009)

movie_review_blurb: In the future, according to The Book of Eli, we'll all dress like we're in a Nine Inch Nails video. It is written.

Director Michael Lembeck shows little imagination in what could have been a quirkier, more interesting kids tale. He does direct surprisingly good hockey sequences, though, including an overhead shot of an airborne tooth.
There's undeniable catharsis -- albeit an ugly, somewhat unsettling catharsis -- in Edge of Darkness.
It's all exceptionally predictable and disappointingly laugh-free, especially since anything with Arnett -- one of the funniest around -- is typically worth the price of admission.
The biggest thing standing in the way of From Paris with Love achieving even that standard is the laughable casting.
The resulting film is an outlandish juggling act. It teeters, creaks and breaks at the seams, but somehow holds together better than you would expect and better than such an extravagant farce should.
Cloaking vigilante justice (not to mention casual racism and homophobia) in religion eventually turns Boondock Saints from merely a bad movie to a distasteful one.
movie_title: The Boondock Saints II: All Saints Day (2009)

movie_review_blurb: The supernatural and its accompanying history of half-vampires and vampaneze never establishes itself as anything but ridiculous.
movie_title: Cirque du Freak: The Vampire's Assistant (2009)

movie_review_blurb: The film isn't shy about its feelings about technology - it's time to unplug. It laments a culture that medicates pain away and has its head in virtual realms.
True to its aim, Jackass 2 probably will leave fans more satisfied than the vast majority of films this year have left moviegoers.
It's disappointing to see Broderick and DeVito try to make mediocre material work.
This is the sort of film that thinks calling a beer a 'libation' is a form of wit.
movie_title: Van Wilder: The Rise of Taj (Van Wilder 2) (2006)

movie_review_blurb: The film never becomes anything of its own, however; it merely jumps from spoof to spoof, often with tenuous transitions.

While The Simpsons Movie is -- like the TV show has become -- too much a caricature of itself, it still possesses good cheer, an aversion to self-seriousness and manic energy for stuffing the screen with layers of humor.
We need to break out a whole new definition of cheesiness for a film like this, augmented by fake tears and vomit gestures.
After 2002's terrible Swept Away and now Revolver, Ritchie has managed to make, back to back, two of the worst films any one director can lay claim to.
When Lee's finally called upon to yell the trademark 'Alllllvin!' it feels like a forced whimper that only reminds us how stale the decades-old material is.
Though the histrionics of City of Men are a bit obvious, and it lacks the bravado of City of God, it's ultimately a more rewarding film.

[Director] Schwimmer shows some skill by keeping the mood light and making no notable missteps, but he still comes away looking like someone trying, and failing, to play Judd Apatow, the reigning champion of realistic, emotional comedy.
As summer movies get bigger and bigger, they often make us, the audience, feel smaller and smaller. The bright Kung Fu Panda is a simple and lighthearted exception.
If this sounds absurd, it is.
movie_title: The Mummy: Tomb of the Dragon Emperor (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Unfortunately, it falls into incredibly predictable territory.
movie_title: How to Lose Friends & Alienate People (2008)

movie_review_blurb: The roles are paper thin, which is too bad considering the talent of the cast. They have all been better. Molina and Leguizamo, in particular, deserve better material.
Most depressing about G-Force is the talent wasted in the name of family entertainment.
Somewhere around the time a giant booger runs riot through the town, one wishes for a bit more adult supervision.
movie_title: Shorts: The Adventures of the Wishing Rock (2009)

movie_review_blurb: It's Kate Beckinsale on Ice.
Terribly Happy, directed by Henrick Ruben Genz, is all moodiness, midnight black comedy and noir mystery.
Most successful is the chemistry between Grace and Hathaway, but with so many swings, that's a pretty low batting average.
Cop Out is a clumsy postmodern buddy cop flick that stuffs as many genre references as it can into the ceaseless patter between Tracy Morgan and Bruce Willis.
Though Burton's film boasts some excellent performances, as the caterpillar says to our heroine, it's merely "almost Alice."
The romance doesn't match the visual splendor, but no matter: The lushness is enough.
The movie is in such a hurry that it doesn't bother to slow down for proper names, instead referring to its main characters as archetypes.
This being the highly advanced 21st century, simple animation won't do, so we must suffer through mediocre, lifeless computer-generated animation of this treasured twosome.
Inarritu is as visually talented as any filmmaker working today, and Biutiful (which was shot by Rodrigo Prieto) is relentlessly detailed. But it's also leaden and contrived.
Unfortunately, Ronny and Nick's bromance takes over, and James has neither the comedy chops or wildness to keep up with Vaughn.
Coppola is brilliant at capturing mood: With cinematographer Harris Savides, her languid camera depicts California melancholy. But substance isn't her game.
There's plenty of atmosphere and awe, even if it's in the service of a story that starts rote and finds its sea legs only when half the divers have sunk their bones to Davy Jones.

The gifted Reilly is now almost principally a comedic actor -- and with good reason. He's the most lovable of goof balls, with his eyes rolling around his sockets crazily and a voice that sounds drunk even when it's sober.
Perhaps a new classification has been born: the "SpaghettiOs Western."
Disaster films will really get interesting when they start running out of iconic skylines to destroy. How about "Battle: Wichita" or "Deep Impact: Albany"?
One feels for the talented actors swept into such hokum.
One feels sympathy for such classic, beloved characters constantly being refashioned for films beneath them. Red Riding Hood needs a better agent.
Warts and all, "Hesher" is still a good shot in the arm.
All of this would be simply banal if not for Waters' surehandedness and Carrey's clever inserts. This is staccato Carrey, throwing in lines and rubbery faces in between the kid movie machinations.
Meester and Cassidy provide solid sidekicks, though that perhaps sells them short: They ultimately carry the movie. All of their storylines lead to self-discovery and sappiness.
An utterly joyless exercise in blood and dirt.

Despite the talents of Greg Kinnear, Pierce Brosnan, Marisa Tomei, Ed Harris, Jennifer Connelly, Ciaran Hinds, Yul Vazquez and Jim Gaffigan, "Salvation Boulevard" is far less than the sum of its fine, character-actor parts.
The rich language of the ruminations are utterly disconnected from Perry's dialogue.
In a cinema world so awash in either corporate flatness or high-art pretension, "The Guard" is a proud, foul-mouthed exception.
Scott has the good sense not to bring everything to a neat conclusion. After all, this is really the Rileys' movie, and one about rebirth and letting go of demons.
Whatever the reasons that draw us to the movies, spending 90 minutes trapped in a box with Ryan Reynolds isn't one of them.
Famuyiwa has made a mostly charming movie despite its cliche milieu.
The Bounty Hunter has little to offer besides some face-time with handsome stars.
The whole thing feels like a joyless slog.
The outer-borough oddities of City Island are hard to resist.
The brothers Edgerton may not be able to summon the dangerous lust or romance of a Cain story, but they can ably supply the wry sense of fate.
The golden-hued "Belle," handsomely made with lavish period detail, has none of the charged friction of its poster.
A movie with prostitutes, guns, boxing and Reno is crying out for the film noir treatment. Along with neon signs in the desert, give us some terse dialogue and some fatalism.
There isn't anything as comically grisly as the exploding head or Carl Weathers' arm removal, both well-remembered moments from the original Predator.

Kline's performance as Henry -- regal in its classical stage pronunciations -- is clearly the best thing in the film. But the character still fails to resonate; Henry isn't much more than a bag of peculiarities.

The scenery is enchanting and it's clear Nadda was inspired to make the film from the beauty of Cairo. She and cinematographer Luc Montpellier succeed in fashioning a graceful postcard to the city, but a story, too, would have been nice.
It's willfully out of date, like an aging hair band that can't pack away the spandex.
There's still a warm, British naturalism to Nanny McPhee Returns and an old-fashioned cheerfulness uncommon to most of today's kids movies.
It's difficult not to want Corbijn's mournful seriousness to ease up a bit. But The American is nevertheless transfixing in its weary, muted grace.
The couple-surrounded-by-quirky-friends dynamic is as obvious as the movie's New York locales and well-positioned indie band posters.
Hoffman reveals Jack the sad sack to be an odd, inarticulate Buddha, willing to put in the work it takes for growth.

Olive is a kind of modern day Ferris Bueller. She has it pretty close to all figured out, and she even gets her own big, gratuitous musical number. It's a terrifically deadpan, lively performance from Stone.
Its familiar story passes with nothing to distinguish itself from the many other similarly plotted movies and sitcoms.
Paranormal Activity 2 is better made and not quite as paper thin as the original, but by replicating the bare-bones B-film, the sequel sacrifices any chance for distinction.
Hunt and Morton don't appear onscreen together until the end of the movie, which makes this feel like two projects forced to mingle.
Awash in 1970s filmmaking and the kind of stylized folksiness that pickling Brooklyn hipsters with handlebar mustaches will positively drool over.
Gray has said he was inspired by Puccini, and with a staggering last shot, "The Immigrant" reaches a crescendo of operatic beauty.
Allied, big and sturdy, always fills the screen. But its gleaming surfaces are missing something underneath.
Pablo Larrain's Jackie, a work of probing intimacy and shattered stereotype, is an electrifyingly fractured portrait of the former First Lady.
Office Christmas Party, cobbled together by six writers, doesn't have the confidence to build its story through the interplay of its employees, and it soon tires of office politics.
What Barry most captures is an Obama struggling to find his identity and his place in the world, highly attuned to his surroundings.
It's a clever enough conceit, doomed by a bungled meet cute.
Fences may never lose the look and sound of a play, but Washington's close-up focus on the characters only heightens the dignity Wilson bestowed on them.
Of the formidable threesome, it's Monae who most stands out.
Ben Younger's Bleed for This, starring Miles Teller, distinguishes itself by doubling down on some of the tried-and-true formulas. It's a comeback times two.

Berg's film isn't seeking answers; it's seeking solace. Patriots Day puts forth a vision of a multicultural society that rises up to reject the fear of terrorism. Its heroes are of all colors, immigrants and Southies, alike.
Farhadi remains a master not just of narrative but of empathy. He's a war correspondent constantly shifting perspective in clandestine battles.
The kind of movie that's fun only when you're laughing at its flaccid attempts at drama.
It turns out to be little more than a monster movie (and a poor one at that) that says more about corporate-driven global moviemaking than anything about either culture.
Get Out, produced by Jason Blum's low-budget horror studio Blumhouse Productions, is serious, even sober in its horror. But its archness has moments of creepy levity.

Ultimately, the film's Vietnam setting is less about warfare and history than finding an intoxicating canvas for a pretty old story. Kong: Skull Island is more about the monster clashes and, as the post-credit clip proves, setting up future installments.
As the film nears its celebratory coda, a buoyant pluralism bursts forth.
Once the alien lifeform strengthens and gets loose, Life surrenders to a tiresome chase away from not just its ravenous creature but from the movies Life so obviously takes it cues from.
The intense charisma of McConaughey is nearly enough to keep Gold from sinking. But the film keeps restyling itself in progressively absurd shifts.
Few could pull off the unapologetically demented nature of Elle like Verhoeven.
The force of Nichols' film is a steadily accumulating one. The Lovings, played with exquisite quietude by Negga and Edgerton, are steadfast and pure.

It's a lot more like a tweed-jacket version of Bond or Bourne or most any other thriller out there. But if Langdon is distinguished from the other globe-trotting saviors by his PhD, why aren't his movies smarter?
Finding Dory, bright and clever like most all Pixar releases, has the animation studio's familiar blend of wit, heart and visual detail. But it's missing its own magic.
Wilderpeople is ultimately winning, like all buddy comedies, because of the chemistry of its leads.
The film, searching for a purpose and some drama, doesn't deserve the grandeur Yates gives it.
The freewheeling and funny solidarity of the four leads win out in the end, even if Feig shows more timidity than he did in Bridesmaids, The Heat or Spy.
Star Trek Beyond, like most of the rebooted properties flying around our movie theaters, delights in nostalgically resurrecting iconic characters and tweaking them anew.
Even when Jason Bourne doesn't click with the same rhythm as its predecessors, it has a weight that outclasses nearly every other big action movie around.
A gleefully nihilistic, abysmally messy romp that delights in upending the genre's conventions and tries desperately to, like, totally blow your mind with its outre freak show.
This is one of the season's most heartening surprises.
The handcrafted textures and wry self-awareness of Kubo and the Two Strings make Knight's film resolutely its own tale, one that folds into its own exotic shape.

Nuanced and charming, Southside With You is a sunny, strolling odyssey through African-American life in 1989, filtered through two future icons as they navigate the world around them and their place in it.
Eastwood moves slowly to the landing but gives it its full due. Filmed on IMAX, his big, clear images nevertheless remain somber -- as does Eastwood's own quiet score - in the big, awaited moment.
Snowden isn't a liberal screed, or at least not an overt one. It's a sincere, straightforward biopic that, at its worst, verges on hagiography.
the movie doesn't have enough to hang itself on; the premise is too flimsy and that old question of "Where babies come from?" remains oddly avoided, in even a child-friendly way.
"Denial" is carried less by the normal theatrics of courtroom dramas than a staunch sense of duty to protect the truth. It's an argument for the patient, methodical dismantling of fools.
Taylor isn't able to believably blend the overlapping perspectives and The Girl on the Train comes across as a flat, predictable puzzle whose characters flip from one extreme to another.

The Accountant is, if nothing else, singular in lending an action-movie cliche an absurdly peculiar and elaborate backstory. "I like incongruity," Wolff says in one scene. The Accountant does, too, but maybe a bit too much.
Keeping Up With the Joneses is, like many before it, just about OK -- but it mostly goes down as another case of funny people stuck in narrowly clichéd roles and an overly familiar story.

Like its sleek, cybernetic protagonist, it's haunted by a fundamental defect -- a bug in the system -- that can't be dispelled, that doesn't pass, despite the considerable cyberpunk splendor of Sanders' eye-popping visual feast.

The horror sequel is a tough thing to pull off in general, and The Conjuring 2 is most certainly one of the better efforts... But, for better or worse, the first movie was just too good and The Conjuring 2 can't hold a candle to its predecessor.
The one-trick act of "Colossal" becomes tiresome even as its leads -- particularly an excellent Hathaway -- work to find some depth in the story.
It's a formally impressive feat -- set nearly entirely in the same rundown warehouse -- but a thin and tedious one.
Despite its flaws, the film gathers an honest force as it burrows deeper into its characters.

Stephen Chbosky's Wonder, despite its Hallmark Card appearance, is far from the exercise in emotional manipulation some might fear. Even the most pessimistic of us may actually find it charming and genuinely affecting.

Nothing is out of place in The Shape of Water, especially its heart. The cast is universally flawless, as is the lavish production design of Paul. D. Austerberry and the sumptuous cinematography of Dan Laustsen.

There's something joyful about the Franco brothers playing a fun-house mirror version of their own Hollywood arrival, and the film's best scenes are with Rogen's production manager, aghast at Tommy's incompetence.

I, Tonya is the Tonya Harding film you never knew you wanted: an outrageously entertaining reappraisal of the Olympic figure skater who, in 1994, was involved in a scheme to injure her main rival, Nancy Kerrigan.
By breaking down some of the old mythology, [Rian] Johnson has staked out new territory. For the first time in a long time, a "Star Wars" film feels forward-moving.
Aside from the audaciousness of its last-minute face-lift, "All the Money in the World" is fairly routine. If Scott was replacing stars, he might as well have yanked Wahlberg while he was at it.
movie_title: All the Money in the World (2017)

movie_review_blurb: The Square, where the enlightened and well-heeled are always gliding past beggars, remains a potent satire.

What the Grahame of Film Stars Don't Die in Liverpool is missing in detail, Bening makes up for in affection. Her performance is a kind of rebuke to the arc and tragic Norma Desmond view of aging movie actresses.
movie_title: Film Stars Don't Die in Liverpool (2017)

movie_review_blurb: With pandering references to the big banks throughout, "The Commuter," has just enough smarts to make its final destination disappointing.
"The Death Cure" is the biggest budgeted, most bloated and longest running entry for the franchise.
It's easy to lament how long it took to bring Black Panther to the big screen. But at least the wait was worth it.
The heroes of the train attack deserve all the praise. But zoom out a little and it's hard not to see Eastwood's America-centric focus in The 15:17 to Paris as self-serving.

Like virtually every science fiction before it, once "Annihilation" - which deviates greatly from the book in its third act - starts solving its enigmas, the spell begins to break. But Garland's film is seldom not something to behold.
Much of Sunday's broadcast, hosted for the second straight year by Jimmy Kimmel, seemed to point a way forward for the industry.
It's a rich ensemble with varying accents, from Cockney to American, and uniform comic brilliance, including Michael Palin as Molotov, Jeffrey Tambor as Malenkov and Jason Isaacs as Zhukov.
To say that the many parts of "In the Fade" are held together by Kruger would be an understatement. As a cocktail of grief, fury and regret, [Dianne Kruger is] a remarkably original protagonist.

A sometimes slight, sometimes serious courtroom drama, shot through with bright certainty in the coming triumphs for Marshall and the civil rights movement. It's a superhero-style origin story: Thurgood, pre-"Brown v. Board of Education," pre-black robe.

While Blade Runner 2049 is always something to look at, an overly elaborate script and some other bad habits common to today's sequel machinery - such as glaring product placement - have broken the Blade Runner spell.

A better barometer for the necessity of Cary Fukunaga's film, however, might be its less-than-literate box office competition. Applying that consideration, maybe we do need this Jane Eyre after all.
The Lincoln Lawyer is an enjoyable piece of pop entertainment.
For a plot about super-intelligent people, the screenplay is surprisingly dumb.
Paul is arguably the best science fiction comedy since Galaxy Quest.
This movie isn't bad in the way some incompetently made movies are bad; this is bad because there's much skill evident in a pointless endeavor.
Source Code is what might happen if one cross-bred Groundhog Day with 24 and The Matrix.
If there's a complaint to be made about Insidious, it's that the film's second half is unable to live up to the impossibly high standards set by the first half.

Technically proficient and featuring a witty, intelligent, surprisingly insightful script, How to Train Your Dragon comes close to the level of Pixar's recent output while easily exceeding the juvenilia Dreamworks has released in the last nine years.
Quote not available.
Quote not available.
movie_title: War Against the Indians - The Feather and the Cross (1992)

movie_review_blurb: The appeal of Drive Angry is much the same as that of Piranha: a willingness to revel in absurdity to the degree where the exhilaration is infectious.
An intriguing, original thriller that owes as much of a debt to the likes of Frankenstein, the Brothers Grimm, David Lynch, and A Clockwork Orange as to The Professional and The Bourne Identity.
Some of the material in Hall Pass is just plain gross, but some of it is damn funny.
The experience of sitting through Just Go with It, Adam Sandler's umpteenth comedy directed by good buddy Dennis Dugan, is akin to watching a bad sit-com that never ends.
It's not good enough to warrant a theatrical showing but not bad enough to deserve universal derision.
Quote not available.
While the melodrama is ladled on fast and thick at times, it is performed with sufficient conviction that we are drawn in rather than left on the outside laughing at it.
Quote not available.

Cage is effective as a falling down drunk in Las Vegas or a treasure hunter navigating goofy road trips but not as a disillusioned champion of the Church going one-on-one with a demon. Steven Seagal would have been more believable.
Among Howard's infrequent misfires, this is one of the most disappointing.
Even as a mindless diversion, it's weak.
An autopsy of a failed marriage, it contrasts the giddy honeymoon beginning with the sad denouement after dysfunction has devastated the groundwork of hope and newness.
For the romantic comedy audience - those who attend movies of this genre out of a genuine love for this sort of thing - No Strings Attached delivers what it promises.
Gene Kelly remains one of the best and brightest of the Golden Era musical stars and An American in Paris shows him in fine form.

The Mechanic is adequate light entertainment for those who enjoy thrillers, but it is uneven and the underwhelming ending will disappoint those who enjoyed the delicious irony served up by its predecessor.
There are some interesting ideas and themes in The Rite; unfortunately, an uneven tone and a disappointingly generic climax dilute them.
There's something about an effective "man versus nature" film that gets the blood pumping.
Quote not available.
movie_title: Behind the Mask: The Rise of Leslie Vernon (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Cedar Rapids is a quirky comedy that crossbreeds two common cinematic staples: the mismatched buddy movie and the fish-out-of-water scenario.
The material keeps our attention but, as we get closer to the inevitable point at which the curtain is pulled back, the movie starts to feel more like a parody than a serious endeavor.
Deneuve is unquestionably the single most compelling reason to see this production.

Driven more by characters and relationships than narrative, Cracks explores the exclusionary power of cliques that develop within a closed society, the single-minded violence of the mob mentality, and the seductive charm of the charismatic individual.
Considering the talent involved on both sides of the camera, audiences may be expecting more - a lot more.
An effective portrait of a damaged individual uncertain about the meaning of love and commitment and the two key relationships in his life that teach him lessons about both.
The result makes the movie seem assembled from bits and pieces of other superhero yarns rather than existing on a plane of its own.
The concept titillates - an oversexed, drug-abusing, foul-mouthed, doesn't-give-a-s--- woman put in charge of a classroom - but the result is drab, obvious, and disappointing.
Although it would be unfair to label Cars 2 as unwatchable, it is surprisingly tedious in parts and not as satisfying as one might expect.
In the future, maybe Bay should abandon using a screenwriter altogether and just fill up 90 minutes with disconnected images of robo-carnage.
As obvious and predictable as this story might be, it still works - in large part because we care about the human beings inhabiting this motion picture.
James can be a funny guy, but the lack of laugh-worthy material in Zookeeper stretches his comedic abilities past the breaking point.
For something like Horrible Bosses to sparkle, the actors have to shine... and shine they do.
The story is involving, the atmosphere is as starkly noir as anything Bogart participated in, and the dynamic between the leads is as conspicuous as ever.

It's almost impossible for the convergence of good and evil to meet inflated expectations. What matters here is that the story is told clearly and with faithfulness to the book, and that it resolves a conflict that has simmered for a decade.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows - Part 2 (2011)

movie_review_blurb: The viewer is left with no clear indication of what really happened, but with a vibrant portrait of a compelling character. That's what Morris is after.
One of the strengths of Friends with Benefits is that Timberlake and Kunis are likeable and display enough chemistry to keep us interested in their inevitable pairing.
A hit-and-miss affair with some scenes and relationships ringing true and others drowning in a deep pool of artifice.
Comic book fans are likely to appreciate Captain America, which does a good job of consolidating the disparate origin aspects of the character into something easily digestible.
Cowboys & Aliens is a mashup of a mediocre Western and a mediocre science fiction story. The resulting film is far better than the sum of its two seemingly disparate parts.
Abrams remembers the simple rule that a majority of his contemporaries have forgotten: action and mayhem have meaning only when an audience cares about the people trapped within the maelstrom.
Striving for no less than the pinnacle of Stanley Kubrick's 2001: A Space Odyssey, The Tree of Life falls short of masterful but retains a power that far too many motion pictures lack.
The setting is Wales during the mid-1980s, but the emotions and characters would be at home in any country in any year.

It's a strangely talky motion picture that tries to advance several philosophical themes; these would have been more interesting if we weren't already aware of how they will play out in the "future" X-Men trilogy.
It's amazing how a lifeless, pointless remake can provoke pangs of nostalgia about a mediocre movie. Such is the case with Arthur.
The only thing surprising about this lackluster animated production is that it attracted an A-list voice cast. But that's how things are today when even mediocre animation can be a big draw.

Scream's brand of horror, which lampooned the slasher genre while simultaneously embracing it, was fun and breezy in 1996. In 2011, it's about as fresh as the whiff of something stale and rank from a crypt.
There's nothing surprising in what Spurlock uncovers, but it illustrates that everything we knew - or at least suspected - about the marriage between advertising and cinema is accurate.
movie_title: POM Wonderful Presents: The Greatest Movie Ever Sold (2011)

movie_review_blurb: The great intangible of chemistry isn't present, making Water for Elephants seem longer and slower than one might hope.

. The basic plot - a man and a woman traveling and talking - is reminiscent of Richard Linklater's Before Sunrise/Before Sunset films, but the way in which Certified Copy calls into question the nature of reality is more akin to Inception.
Ignoring the rules of physics doesn't make a movie more entertaining; it merely makes the writing easier. If a screenplay can cheat at any time, it encourages sloppy authorship.
The chief sin committed by Gulliver's Travels is not that it's a poor adaptation but that its entertainment value is almost nonexistent.
A successful romantic comedy should offer breezy wish fulfillment as sweet and airy as cotton candy. Something Borrowed is overlong and at times tedious; the taste is gritty and lingers unpleasantly.
The setup is ripe for a black comedy but the movie never fully embraces the darkness and the level of humor is on par with the limp skits for which Wiig is responsible on Saturday Night Live.
I was not waiting for a punch line. I was not primed to laugh. I accepted Ferrell as Nick and, because of that, I was able to enjoy Everything Must Go on its own terms.
For all his faults, Gore Verbinski at least handled the action with panache. Those movies thrummed with derring-do. This one sinks.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: On Stranger Tides (2011)

movie_review_blurb: It's an entertaining trifle that is at least as engaging as, and perhaps more likeable than, a majority of the filmmaker's recent excursions.
Using the original as a template, The Hangover Part II colors within the lines, but does so with bright fluorescents rather than drab primaries.
Jack Black once again shows his excellence as a voice actor.
I suspect parents will react more strongly to this movie than non-parents. It's hard to imagine anyone, however, leaving the theater without a more thoughtful perspective.
Branagh's Thoris big enough and bold enough to fit under the Marvel umbrella but infused with sufficient uniqueness to make it work for those weary of generic superhero stories.
Those who venture into Rabbit Hole with their expectations properly aligned will leave fulfilled and perhaps with a slightly different perspective on a few things.
Sofia Coppola has strayed into an area of pretentiousness that we have rarely seen since the height of the French New Wave.

Despite a tremendous performance by Hawkins, I was never engaged by the struggle of these women. Their fight may have been historical in its impact, but there's little sense that the personal stakes are high.
The cast is effective, with everyone sliding believably into their roles.
Killer Instinct is generally fast-paced but the need to cram about 15 years of Mesrine's life into less than two hours results in uneven patches.
It's hard to imagine anyone who sees the movie not being at least moderately engaged.
There's nothing special or memorable about this overlong endeavor, the first of two motion pictures to feature Bing Crosby's insufferably noble Father Chuck O'Malley.
For most of Piranha 3D, Aja skates along the line separating satire/camp from horror without straying into the realm of outright parody.
To date, no motion picture has adequately captured the soaring highs and devastating lows associated with a long distance relationship, but Going the Distance comes as close as any movie has.
Anyone who understands what The American offers should come away pleased with the final product.
I have nothing against films that take political stances, but an exploitation flick? It's off-putting. I'd prefer to sit back and bask in the carnage and R-rated silliness.
It's refreshing to see someone putting the needs of the part over her image, and this is far from a halfhearted performance. It's gritty and gutsy.
It's kind of a low-budget, grungy looking Superbad without the stupid cop stuff.
Flipped is Rob Reiner's best film in 18 years.
With a crisp, clear style and a focus on character, director Ben Affleck is able to imbue staple action scenes with a sense of urgency and tension.
Easy A belongs in the company of Election, Heathers, and Mean Girls -- all motion pictures that have outlived their theatrical lives because they have unique voices and use them to say something.
At best a cheesy, unsatisfying thriller and, at worst, a waste of time.
Romanek, a highly respected music video director making his follow-up to One Hour Photo, has crafted a motion picture that is as visually impressive as it is emotionally distant.
No one can claim the bloodshed was toned down in the quest for a PG-13 -- and I consider that to be a positive quality.
Quote not available.
movie_title: After The Cup: Sons Of Sakhnin United (2010)

movie_review_blurb: While Wilde's wit remains firmly entrenched, there's also a gruesome vein of gothic horror, and elements of the original which existed in the subtext or were merely hinted at are brought graphically into the open.
The film is tiresome not merely because of the familiarity of the material, but because there's little verve surrounding the proceedings.
Two-thirds of the way through, The Millennium Trilogy is looking like the North American cinematic event of 2010.
movie_title: The Girl Who Played with Fire (Flickan som lekte med elden) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Predator fans, fearing another lapse into disappointment, can relax. Although it's arguably not saying much, this is the second-best movie of the series to have "Predator" in the title.
This is a smartly written comedy with a soft emotional core.
The movie isn't so much bad as it is formulaic and uninspired. In some ways, that might almost be a worse sin.
All it asks of viewers is that they do something rare: engage the intellect.
There comes a point when it becomes difficult to take Salt seriously. That would be fine if this was an intentional parody of action spy thrillers, but it's not.
Life During Wartime relies on uncomfortable black humor and moments of sincere drama to involve viewers. But everything is encased in artifice and the movie becomes a chore to take in.
In the end, it's just a tale of passable interest and questionable authenticity.
The Father of My Children is exceptional drama. Compelling and unforced, it shows sensitivity and evenhandedness in approaching a difficult subject.
movie_title: The Father of My Children (Le pere de mes enfants) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Countdown to Zero is worthwhile to an extent, if that extent is largely to remind the viewer of certain facts that are easily shunted to the back of one's consciousness.
Steers and his screenwriters aren't aiming for logic; they're leading up to the next opportunity for Efron to remove his shirt.
For the most part, the jokes have punch lines, which is too rarely the case in big-budget comedies.
An overlong bore that either mistakenly thinks it's something more than a humdrum romance or has incorporated a variety of pretentions as window-dressing.
A clever send-up of comic book and video games (circa 1990), this movie illustrates that writer/director Edgar Wright can rise to the next level.
The movie is as powerful today as when it captured the Best Picture Oscar a few years after Hitler's genocide ended in Europe.
All that's good about The Switch is undermined by the need to conform to romantic comedy standards and by the predictable performance of a miscast Jennifer Aniston.
The film is sporadically amusing but gives the impression it should be generating more laughs than it does.
The screenplay is smart, the execution is impeccable, and the holes are few and far between.
In the same way it's impossible to turn away from a grisly accident, taking your eyes away from Ryan Reynolds' hypnotizing performance is not an option.
Let Me In represents one of the best and most brutal vampire movies to come along in a while...
The Next Three Days offers enough suspense to make it worth the price of admission.
Despite the need to wear flimsy plastic glasses, watching Tangled reminds one that some brands of storytelling never go out of style, whatever that style may be.
Love and Other Drugs may be the most honest romance to grace the screens during all of 2010.
As films of this genre go, Faster is a middle-of-the-road offering, but those expecting something fast-paced and frenetic are likely to be disappointed.
Black Swan makes the contortions of Shutter Island and Inception seem facile by comparison.
Although the movie posits a solution to an infamous missing person's case, it does so in a manner that is less than satisfying.
The "quest" element, a common fantasy staple, is uninspired and perfunctory, and there's a growing sense throughout the movie that there's no real point to any of what is occurring.
movie_title: The Chronicles of Narnia: The Voyage of the Dawn Treader (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Perhaps the most disappointing aspect of I Love You Phillip Morris is its inability to maintain the high level at which it begins -- a withering lampoon of wholesome, middle class values.
They had 28 years, and this is the best they could come up with?

Spacey is the reason to see Casino Jack. This movie will stand alongside The Usual Suspects and American Beauty as examples of what the actor is capable of accomplishing when he is properly motivated.
It does some of what it sets out to accomplish and most viewers will depart the theater with at least the beginnings of a warm, fuzzy feeling. These days, it's hard to ask for much more.
Quote not available.
Rarely does a comedy bring such an overpowering sense of sadness.
True Grit, one of the best films of 2010, is a reminder of why remakes are not always bad.
A fully satisfying and uplifting period piece that achieves its dramatic potential without sacrificing historical accuracy.
The movie builds erratically to the moment when the end credits start rolling. After sacrificing nearly 2 1/2 hours to this movie, there's a sense that more is deserved.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows - Part 1 (2010)

movie_review_blurb: How this managed not to go direct-to-DVD (and actually get a wide distribution rather than just a handful-of-theaters dump) is one of 2010's great cinematic mysteries.
The portrait of Spitzer that emerges throughout Client 9 is of a straight-talking, no-nonsense individual whose non-political way of getting things done crafted a lot of enemies.
movie_title: Client 9: The Rise and Fall of Eliot Spitzer (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Unstoppable, a 95-minute thrill ride from director Tony Scott, delivers the right level of adrenaline. Unfortunately, the sheer exhilaration is dampened somewhat by an overreliance upon action/thriller stock situations and characters.
This is the 2010 Oscar season's first drama to live up to the hype and expectations associated with it.
Some parts of the movie are more satisfying and intriguing than others, but there are enough surprising and non-intuitive revelations that even the most jaded viewer will likely learn a thing or two.

The racing sequences are effectively done and Secretariat's quest for horse racing's Triple Crown concludes with one of those stand-up-and-cheer moments, but the story as a whole seems stale and overly familiar.
Cloying and at times annoying, Life as We Know It is egregiously manipulative, whoring itself out for a few unearned tears.
The acting is strong, with Galifianakis doing an especially good job as the likeable Bobby.
movie_title: It's Kind of a Funny Story (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Not to be confused with the early-'90s Kieslowski film of the same name. Definitely not.
A Best Picture hopeful? Or a watered-down marriage between The Hurricane and Erin Brockovich? Perhaps both.
There are times when iconic characters should be left alone to bask in the glory of a single appearance and, unfortunately, that's the case with Gordon Gekko.

The craftsmanship is impeccable as is the acting, but the storytelling is where the movie falls down. And with such a poorly realized narrative, it's hard to be enthusiastic about the many things Stone does right.
The clumsy and obvious byproduct of the financial success of its predecessor last Halloween, this movie has no reason for existing except to provide Paramount Pictures with a few extra shekels.
Who said science fiction films have to be expensive?
Unlike The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo, which can stand on its own, the other two films need to be seen as a set. Neither is complete without the other.
movie_title: The Girl Who Kicked the Hornet's Nest (2010)

movie_review_blurb: 127 Hours is unflinching in its depiction of what constitutes the "will to live."
Megamind is largely what one might expect from an animated movie featuring a number of notable comedians in voice roles: an amusing diversion.
Phillips seems to have forgotten that bawdy comedy is only deemed "edgy" if it's funny. When the seedy jokes fall flat, the result is crass.
Despite the conventional manner in which the story is resolved, Morning Glory generates enough entertainment, good will, and genuine laughs to make it hard to dislike.
It's safe to say that, as a director, Clint Eastwood shows no fear.

Rush not only effectively presents a balanced view of the rivalry between two race car drivers but manages the difficult task of taking Formula One racing, an inherently non-cinematic sport, and translating it to the screen.
Don Jon is visually interesting without being overbearing. The script finds a witty way to confront serious issues. And Levitt-Gordon takes on the personality of a guy straight out of Jersey Shore.
The jarring shifts between effective drama and failed humor make watching Enough Said a bumpy and sometimes frustrating journey.
It was always one of 2016's most anticipated films and it doesn't let down the legions who have been waiting for it.
movie_title: Rogue One: A Star Wars Story (2016)

movie_review_blurb: The title character never emerges from the iconic shell she inhabits to become a fully fleshed-out individual and the filmmakers are perhaps too reverential to make her seem real.
If there's one constant about Collateral Beauty, it's how consistently it disappoints.

Most of Sing's creative energy was invested in the musical numbers and, fortunately, that's where it shines. But the film really can't go toe-to-toe with heavyweights Zootopia, Moana, Dory or even the little-seen but superior Kubo.
Passengers is an odd movie but its central questions and dilemmas are compelling and there's enough here of substance for the impressions to linger. Problems aside, it's a journey worth taking.
Obtuse, narratively incoherent, and ultimately frustrating, it stands as another example of how hard it is to make a good mainstream movie out of a popular computer game.

Hidden Figures provides an example of determination and talent triumphing over an unfair and repressive system - something that ... has relevance beyond the decade or the century in which it transpires.
Yes, Fences suffers somewhat from the bare-bones transferal of the "action" from stage to screen but the material is so compelling that viewers can easily lose sight of the movie's "play nature."
I'm not going to lie. I laughed - just not as frequently or as hard as I would have liked to.
Lion represents a commitment from those involved and, flaws aside, it's an amazing tale of resilience and determination.
A Monster Calls is an unexpectedly powerful and unsentimental exploration of surviving grief and the less-than-noble feelings it can engender.
The movie eventually achieves a level of powerful drama...but only after dithering for more than an hour.
As an actor, Affleck is a strong, reassuring presence; his performance is an anchor holding things in place and allowing for a flotilla of strong supporting portrayals.
Berg's chronicle of the 2013 Boston Marathon bombings and the subsequent manhunt is a first rate docudrama.

The Founder represents two hours well-spent, especially for anyone with a fascination for complex characters or an interest in the shenanigans that transformed an unpretentious local restaurant into a global force.
It's more vibrant than Chicago, more heartfelt than Les Miserables, and more successfully staged than a chorus of other contenders.
The narrative is choppy, the tension is less pervasive than it should be, and there's no ending.

As a dramatic thriller, it does what it needs to do to keep the audience involved and interested, even if some of its most theatrical tricks and twists are more the products of a writer's invention than actual Washington D.C. activities.
Unforced acting couples with a nuanced, insightful script to tell a story that, although seemingly simple, is achingly complex.
A paint-by-numbers, creatively bankrupt "comedy" emerging from a studio system that has largely forgotten what it means to be genuinely funny.
Although it's not possible to argue that Philip Roth's 1997 Pulitzer Prize-winning book couldn't be made into a powerful, compelling film, this isn't it.
The Da Vinci Code was adequate but forgettable. Angels & Demons was godawful. Inferno is somewhere in between - watchable but by no means worth the money and effort necessary to see it theatrically.
Chan-wook Park's The Handmaiden is deliciously perverse, delightfully twisty, and unapologetically erotic.
Hacksaw Ridge embraces many of the clichés of the war movie but, instead of laying them out in a rote fashion, the film synthesizes them into a visceral, ultimately inspirational result.
Doctor Strange tells a standard tale with just enough cleverness to keep the viewer interested.
If Arrival succeeds at the box office, it will shine as a beacon in favor of not dumbing down every production to appease the distracted and disinterested masses.
Effectively acted and occasionally moving, the film both benefits from and is undermined by writer/director Jeff Nichols' no-frills approach to the circumstances leading up to the court case.
The best parts of Fantastic Beasts are those that deal with the immediate storyline. Those that seek to extend the narrative are less interesting.
movie_title: Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them (2016)

movie_review_blurb: This movie leaves an impression that's difficult to shake.
With a smart, perceptive script from first-time director Kelly Fremon Craig and an arresting lead performance by Hailee Steinfeld, the film rises to the top of a crowded genre.

Despite moments of emotional strength and bursts of quirky comedy, the film is undone by its generally lethargic tone and the film's insistence to shift its focus from the putative lead characters to a supporting player ...
Moana is solid "retro Disney" - a new film that embraces older ideas, themes, and narrative approaches.
Allied isn't a great film but it's made with sufficient care and skill that it deserves to be seen.
At its best, Bad Santa 2 feels like an echo of its predecessor. At its worst, it's unfunny, crass, and uncomfortable (not in a good way).
Although Barry Jenkins' film is indeed about the struggles and difficulties of a person embracing his culturally reviled sexuality, the story is universal in scope and intent.
Jam-packed with tedious, over-the-top action and testosterone-fueled machismo, Return of Xander is a throwback to a time when all action films were made for teenage boys.
Despite its uneven tone, the film is compelling and, perhaps more importantly, relevant even though the actual historical events occurred two decades ago.
Elle's moral ambiguity and controversial content are its strengths.
If it's remembered at all, it will be seen as a missed opportunity to tell a powerful story.
It would be a stretch (although not much of one) to call Going in Style "wholesome" but it's dull and badly in need of an injection of energy.
Movies like Gifted often drift into a quagmire of manipulation and over-the-top histrionics. For the most part, however, Webb avoids this path.
You know what you're getting before you go, and you get it.
Although the narrative for Their Finest occasionally rambles ... it is by-and-large a stirring drama that incorporates lighter moments with scenes of deeply felt tragedy.
Although at times overwrought and overtly manipulative, the film as a whole is like a kick to the gut.
Although The Lost City of Z held my interest, it felt like a missed opportunity. Like too many biographical movies, this one tries to do too much.
For those who don't mind a little blood & gore and a lot of profanity, Free Fire is a superior alternative to the big-name, bloated action films hogging the largest screens in most multiplexes.
From its beginning, the movie has difficulty wedding its collage of ideas with a compelling narrative.
Volume 2 can claim to be bigger and better than its predecessor, although it still suffers from some of the narrative sleight-of-hand issues that kept Guardians of Galaxy from achieving greatness.
The movie is funnier than most so-called comedies and works as a breezy 90-minute diversion but it's a less ambitious endeavor than Trainwreck.
Kinetic and attention-grabbing.
movie_title: King Arthur: Legend Of The Sword (2017)

movie_review_blurb: As YA romances go - and there are plenty to choose from - this is a lesser option.
Alien: Covenant combines high-minded sci-fi ideas with the visceral horror-inspired shock aspects of a slasher movie.
An example of lazy writing and direction with the vague hope that perhaps the involvement of Dwayne "The Rock" Johnson will attract viewers.
Ghost in the Shell is visually compelling but tone deaf.
Those who have seen Alien will have a pretty good idea what's coming, at least to a point. Once things reach that point, however, all bets are off.
Nothing in T2 is memorable.
The production is in equal parts mesmerizing and perplexing, intriguing and frustrating.
The Space between Us is what it looks like when a promising premise is betrayed by a dumbed-down, hackneyed screenplay.
This is a bad film - at times it's nigh unwatchable - but that doesn't matter in the grand scheme of things.
Overall, The Lego Batman Movie offers enough action and silliness to enthrall children while providing sufficient pop culture and Batman-through-the-years references to keep adults entertained.
This is "more of the same" but, at least in this case, that's a good thing.
A United Kingdom never sacrifices its narrative in favor of making a statement and it rarely resorts to sermonizing.
Although the story is slight, the film leaves viewers with a lasting, haunting impression.
There's no rule that main characters have to be likable, and DeHaan's Lockhart isn't, but they at least have to be interesting. He fails that litmus test.
Jack Reacher: Never Go Back is a jumble of overhyped action scenes, trite dialogue, painfully bad "character development", and awful writing.

More galling and tedious than funny, this quasi-re-imagining of the 1987 high school film, Three O'Clock High, proves that it's entirely possible for a remake of a bad movie to be worse than its inspiration.
The praiseworthy quality of Get Out is that it delivers the goods without copycatting every cookie-cutter horror film being released today.
With his glimpse into what superhero movies can be, James Mangold has given us something sadly lacking in recent genre entries: hope.
It takes a mediocre movie like Before I Fall to illustrate how brilliant Harold Ramis' Groundhog Day is.
If the ultimate point of this movie is to get Kong into the ring with Godzilla, this isn't a bad appetizer.
Condon's version is capable of enthralling but if those who treasure the animated telling find it at times wanting, that shouldn't be a surprise.
Raw feels unformed - a collage of partially realized ideas and moments that never gel.
Watching The Sense of an Ending, I was struck by the realization that this should have been a good movie.
If this is the future for motion pictures, god help us all.
It's fast paced but goes nowhere new and the film's "bigness" makes it hard to remember what an amazingly unexpected treasure The Curse of the Black Pearl was.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: Dead Men Tell No Tales (2017)

movie_review_blurb: A movie that could easily have been familiar, disposable entertainment but is made with sufficient competence and energy to capture the viewer's attention and linger a little after the end credits have rolled.
Are you a Kevin Hart fan? Then drop everything and rush to see this movie. Are you not a Kevin Hart fan? Then move along, there's nothing here to see...
Generic animated cash-grab.
The production doesn't offer much in the way of originality but it's a tense 90-minute ride that will result in elevated pulses, increased respiration, and white knuckles.
As far as big superhero mash-ups are concerned, this one whets the appetite without providing a satisfying main course.
Is it A Bigger Splash or A Bigger Bore?

Unfortunately, despite a surfeit of talent in front of and behind the camera, the movie is unable to overcome a shaky narrative whose increasing preposterousness ensures it's difficult to take seriously.

The film overflows with quips, irony, and physical gags while at the same time relating a noir-tinged story of seedy corruption set in the neon-saturated underbelly of the 1977 Los Angeles porn industry.
There are about six really good laughs during the film's 92-minute running length.
There's not enough here for a full length feature film - something that becomes obvious the longer the movie is on the screen.
As a superhero movie in general and an X-Men movie in particular, Apocalypse delivers everything a viewer could reasonably expect from it.
Visually, Alice through the Looking Glass has its moments but pretty backgrounds and clever special effects can't obscure the disappointment resulting from a half-baked script and a miscast villain.
Too often ... it feels lazy and derivative and it's difficult to recommend something that, despite offering a few solid laughs, is instantly forgettable.
It's not perfect - there are times when the pacing is off and the epilogue tries too hard to end things on a positive note - but it's effective and affecting.
The Conjuring 2 proves that, with a sufficient investment of time and energy, sequels don't have to be unsatisfying cash-grabs.
Based solely on merit, Now You See Me 2 is a sequel that should never have been made.
Large scale battles and magical pyrotechnics are nice supplements but the absence of well-formed characters and a meaningful narrative render such pretty things moot.
By cramming far too much material into 114 minutes, The Huntsman: Winter's War feels rushed and incomplete.
With its canned, predictable action sequences and mirthless attempts at humor, it displays an ineptitude that is frankly shocking considering the talent involved.
The Jungle Book is well-made and deserves recognition as one of the year's best family offerings (thus far).
Thank god for Jake Gyllenhaal. Absent his performance, Demolition would have been a more unbearable slog than it is.
Taron Egerton reproduces Eddie's offbeat charm, turning him into an Asperger's afflicted champion of the undertrodden.
Hillcoat's approach is to craft a pulse-pounding experience that employs a mixture of conventional footage and hand-held work. There's an immediacy to the most gripping scenes.
If one is going to make special effects the focus of a movie, they need to be good special effects, and that's not the case here. Proyas' ideas are never fully translated from imagination to screen.
London Has Fallen is competently made and offers what any viewer would reasonably expect. There's plenty of action, a fair amount of wide-scale destruction, and a rousing climax.
Tina Fey is the biggest asset but even she's not sufficient to make it worth more than a marginal recommendation and a suggestion to wait until it shows up on home video.
Something like The Wave is indeed a rarity - without skimping on the spectacle that glues eyeballs to the screen, it takes the time to develop its characters.
There's a lot here for kids to like and nearly as much to keep parents from fidgeting.
Take away the disappointing, disjointed, and anti-climactic final act, and this is an effective white-knuckle psychological thriller.
A production that fails in every way at every turn.
Allegiant exemplifies what happens when a book or movie exists solely for the purposes of placating fans and maintaining a revenue stream.
Creative Control looks more interesting than it is.
Although viewers may be riveted at times, the net experience isn't much fun.
movie_title: Batman v Superman: Dawn of Justice (2016)

movie_review_blurb: What we're left with is something that recalls Crocodile Dundee in L.A. - the misbegotten notion that bringing back characters long past their sell-by date is a good idea.
Eye in the Sky is compelling, offering the best elements of a drama and a thriller.
Although this may be "lesser" Linklater, it's still more enjoyable than a lot of what's currently available in theaters.
Criminal is an action-thriller with a science fiction twist. To the extent that its purpose is to energize and involve an audience, it succeeds.
Finding Dory is enjoyable in its own right, even if its powerful sense of déjà vu keeps it from approaching the pinnacle of the Disney/Pixar collaborations.
The Shallows is almost a good movie.
Pretentious and self-indulgent, it seems tailor-made to appeal to lovers of the obtuse and inscrutable until it takes a left-turn into schlocky, gore-drenched splatter imagery.
From a purely narrative perspective, there's nothing new here but like a new arrangement of a familiar tune, the slight changes make it fresh and enjoyable.
Traditional and uninspired, it does an adequate job of relating Duran's story but falls short of providing an engaging cinematic experience.
It's an attempt to wed philosophical science fiction concepts with bloody horror - a dubious endeavor that somehow works.
Contrivances and melodrama aside, it is emotionally true and that's often the most important thing for a film of this nature.
A loving tribute in general to Star Trek and in particular to the man who gave more than half of his life to Spock.
Although not an Oscar-worthy endeavor, Sully proves to be by turns engaging, exhilarating, and nail-biting.
Snowden could have been an important film. It certainly contains important elements. Sadly, unlike its subject, it's unremarkable and easily forgotten.
It's funny and engaging and the lead character, again played by Renee Zellweger, seems more like a real person than the caricature who wandered dazed through The Edge of Reason.
Perhaps for someone who never saw The Blair Witch Project, this might represent an adequate scary movie.
If there's a compelling reason to remake The Magnificent Seven, it can't be found in the 2016 version, a loud, cluttered, and generally disappointing production.
The main characters are well established and director Peter Berg does a good job building tension toward the historically inevitable cataclysm that kills 11 people and wrecks the drilling platform.

Overall, despite feeling a little long and suffering from a rushed ending, Miss Peregrine's Home for Peculiar Children is a fresh and engaging storybook adventure that should appeal to viewers both inside and out of the core demographic.
movie_title: Miss Peregrine's Home for Peculiar Children (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Masterminds finds plenty of targets for its satirical jabs and lets them all off the hook.
The film stands tall on its own merits and deserves to be seen irrespective of the perceived failings of its author.
Although The Girl on the Train is a serviceable thriller, it's hard not to see it as something of a disappointment.
An amateurish effort that boasts direct-to-video characteristics, the latest version disappoints in almost every production aspect.
A diverting but by no means indispensable expose of the international arms black market.
Kubo and the Two Strings is a magical motion picture in every sense of the word.
The movie builds - something infinitely preferable to a bold, brash beginning followed by a descent into anti-climax.
The temptation is there to say that Independence Day: Resurgence tarnishes the image of its predecessor but the original Independence Day wasn't all that good to begin with.
The Purge: Election Year represents writer/director James DeMonaco's attempt to squeeze one more movie out of a premise that has run dry.
In recent years, Spielberg has become a hit-and-miss filmmaker and this is closer to a "miss" than a "hit."
The Legend of Tarzan moves briskly and has the overall feel of one of Burroughs' more entertaining stories come to the screen.
There's nothing clever here. The filmmakers believe that broad, obvious gags, pratfalls, and profanity-laced tirades are inherently funny. They're not.
movie_title: Mike and Dave Need Wedding Dates (2016)

movie_review_blurb: The Secret Life of Pets is strong enough that parents won't fall into a catatonic state while watching it with their offspring.
Furman keeps a tight rein on the film's palpable, sometimes suffocating tension. It's one of The Infiltrator's assets. Another is the ensemble cast.
It's strangely refreshing to watch a courtroom drama where theatricality doesn't trump meticulous examination and cross-examination.
This is a mediocre horror/comedy that deserves neither high praise nor disparagement.
Unfortunately, the film stumbles, offering too few legitimate scares and displaying an overreliance on traditional horror movie clichés.
It is at times very funny and its unwillingness to pull punches (which, it must be noted, doesn't always work) is bracing.
Star Trek Beyond is a Star Trek movie, although not an especially good one.

Matt Ross' screenplay occasionally stumbles (especially late in the proceedings) and the ending opts for a too-facile resolution but the director/writer offers moments of genuine power and pathos that make it easy to forgive the missteps.
Joost and Schulman use nearly every trick imaginable to keep Nerve's energy at a consistently high level and to give it a visual uniqueness.
Despite regurgitating elements from the founding trilogy, Jason Bourne represents the best the series has yet offered.
[A] bloated and cheerless monstrosity.
Ice Age: Collision Course, the fifth installment in this lamentably long-lived animated franchise, is the last Ice Age movie I intend to see.
The real strengths of this production are its lead actors, the period piece setting, and an unexpected emotional resonance that one doesn't expect from a popcorn movie.
The movie is fresh, fun, and breezy.
movie_title: Captain Underpants: The First Epic Movie (Captain Underpants) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Narratively incoherent and full of cheese and camp, this movie makes it clear that the mummy should have remained dead and buried.
At some point just past the middle, it goes on autopilot.
The next time these characters band together, perhaps they will do so with stronger backgrounds, a real sense of purpose, and a story that's more than a cobbled-together mess.
It starts with a bang, ends with a bang, and those scenes bookend some solid character moments and tense, atmospheric filmmaking. This small gem is worth seeking out.

The movie, like the book, takes a long, hard look at the system of racial inequality that defined this time and place, and reminds viewers of the price to be paid for surrendering to our base instincts.
Oldman immerses himself so deeply in the role that the actor disappears.
Coco may not represent Disney/Pixar at its pinnacle but it's close enough to the top to warrant consideration as the best computer-drawn film of 2017.
Takes the viewer on a dizzying ride through dark comedy, wrenching tragedy, shocking moments, karmic twists, and redemption.
The Man Who Invented Christmas contains nothing inappropriate for family viewing, but I'd be hard-pressed to find a family that would find the experience enriching.
The story is surprisingly unfocused and, when it snaps out of the protracted setup phase, it plunges into quasi-thriller territory that relies on a series of hard-to-swallow contrivances.
I can understand where there is value in showing this film to younger children because the message, albeit sanitized, will resonate.
It's hard to come away from this film and not believe that, in his heart, writer/director del Toro is a romantic.

A fascinating glimpse into the genesis of one of Hollywood's worst releases and is worthy of a space alongside Ed Wood on the shelf for dreamers who succeeded because of a lack of self-awareness and an epic void of talent.
Although the surface tone adopted by I, Tonya is breezy and cheeky, there's a lot going on beneath the facade.
It's a story of first love: impossible, impermanent, and passionate.
Wonder Wheel seems more like a cobbled-together afterthought than the romantic melodrama it seeks to be.
Seen as a pure holiday comedy, Daddy's Home 2 works fine.
There's a sense that Johnson is giving busy-work to certain characters while others are catching up. The Last Jedi is a great 105-minute movie stretched too thin.
A thoughtful meditation about war and surviving in its aftermath, Last Flag Flying avoids descending into the hell where many such movies take us and, as a result, is more hopeful and life-affirming.

Highlighted by an awards-worthy performance by Saoirse Ronan and structured around a light, witty script by Gerwig, the movie delivers a well-targeted snapshot of a year-in-the-life of an ordinary high school senior.
Although the production is sporadically amusing, it feels like a 20-minute short that was expanded to feature length to its considerable detriment.
Breathe has moments of emotional resonance but the overall experience feels flat and familiar.
Although probably a little too long, the film succeeds in being both emotionally forceful and dramatically satisfying.

One of the most shockingly awful wastes of talent imaginable, this adaptation of Jo Nesbo's thriller is mostly incoherent and, just when it starts to make sense, it is hijacked by a series of laughably bad clichés.
Winnie the Pooh is timeless and unforgettable. The same qualities don't apply to this tale of the real-life people and circumstances that inspired his creation.
Deeply unsettling and hard to shake.
