movie_title: The Killing of a Sacred Deer (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Wonderstruck is an evocative movie with a vaguely disappointing narrative that, although it reaches a conclusion, doesn't justify the patience viewers must exhibit to reach that point.
Thank You for Your Service is straightforward drama and leaves an uneasy impression about how much more the recipients of that platitude are owed than what the government is giving them.
The good parts of The Square - and there are quite a few of them - can't overcome the weaknesses, making this a decidedly mixed bag.
Despite an interesting premise and a promising first act, All I See Is You ultimately fails to deliver much beyond a gradual descent into disinterest and watch-checking.
Suburbicon goes immediately to the front of the line of contenders for the most disappointing film of 2017.
Superhero fans deserve better than this. Battles should have heart, danger, and consequences. The conflicts in Thor: Ragnarok are lacking in all three.
Although it offers occasional chuckles and even a few solid, laugh-out-loud moments, the picture as a whole seems redundant and superfluous.
It is being touted as "Miike's 100th film" and, while one could argue whether the numbering is strictly correct, it's close enough to be reasonable. Here's to another 100.
movie_title: Blade of the Immortal (Mugen no jûnin) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Perhaps the most remarkable thing about Novitiate is the even-handedness with which it treats religion in general and 1960s era Catholicism in particular.
Although the film will work considerably better for newcomers to the story, there's enough here to appeal to veterans.
Although prone to occasional sermonizing, The Post offers a stirring reminder of the importance of these kinds of unsung heroes in protecting the American way of life.
Cooper doesn't cheapen the subject matter by introducing "lighter" moments that would seem inappropriate. This is an entirely serious movie about important matters.
Every year, there are a handful of pleasant and unpleasant surprises in multiplexes. Count Jumanji: Welcome to the Jungle among the former.
Double Lover may not represent Ozon in peak form but it's too weirdly entertaining to dismiss out-of-hand.
This is 2018's first great motion picture - a title that will surely be remembered when "end of the year" bests are discussed.
For Cage, this is a big step back toward respectability.
So generic and perfunctory in nature that it's difficult to become involved or stay immersed in the action.
The Cured is flawed but it's easier to forgive the problems associated with an ambitious vision than something interested only in providing an evening's distraction.
Potter's script is deft, breezing along quickly. The comedy is low-key and of a more intellectual than physical variety.
This movie, unlike something produced for mass audiences, is about what happens in the calm moments between the loud, splashy sequences.
Game Night is canny enough to go full-throttle with the absurd and not bother trying to do much with its meager dramatic and/or sentimental elements.

By focusing more on suspense and tension than gore, the brothers Ramsay (director Julius, writer Alston) have crafted an economical and effective alternative to the many disappointing big-budget entries into this genre.
On balance, Red Sparrow is a reasonable choice for those who don't mind a fair amount of graphic sex and violence mixed in with the spying, back-stabbing, and double-dealing expected from this genre.
It's fair to ask what new things Eli Roth and Bruce Willis bring to Death Wish that the original, made in 1974 with Charles Bronson, didn't have. The answer is: not many.
I have no doubt that Geoghegan's intentions are sincere but the muddling of historical fiction with the Grand Guignol is an uneven mix that never fully gels.
Although there are a few missteps, the movie boasts a deliciously dark tone that makes for compelling viewing.

I left the theater vaguely annoyed - as if the filmmakers had thrown away some promising ideas and elements in weaving together a thoroughly generic chase movie and pretending it's something special by employing ineffective stylistic choices.
Unfortunately, the slow pace of the first hour coupled by the tedium of a CGI overload, reduces A Wrinkle in Time to one of Disney's most lackluster big-budget releases since The BFG.

Basmati Blues isn't nearly as bad as some of the online buzz might indicate...and that's actually unfortunate. Instead of vying for a so-bad-it's-entertaining categorization, it falls squarely into the hell of cinematic mediocrity.
This is as surprising a romantic comedy as I have seen in some time.
The sex scenes are strangely mechanical and devoid of passion. It's probably a mixture of three things: directorial decisions, a lack of chemistry between the leads, and viewer apathy.
A kluge of bad science and worse science fiction clichés, it tries to be atmospheric and scary but succeeds only at being frustrating and tedious.
It's a family film whose infectious, crowd-pleasing song-and-dance numbers justify a 105-minute running length when the pedestrian story can't.
Unfortunately, the central character is as small figuratively as he is literally, and that limits the movie's capacity to enthrall and engage.
When Getty isn't on-screen, the movie is a bit of a bore and it doesn't help that Mark Wahlberg is woefully miscast and the thriller elements are anything but tense or suspenseful.
movie_title: All the Money in the World (2017)

movie_review_blurb: It's all good stuff, delivered by a director who knows how to get the most out of performers speaking his words.
For Daniel Day-Lewis' final acting job, he gives it his all, playing fashion designed Reynolds Woodcock as a tightly-wound ball of impulses, quirks, and foibles.
The frequent chronological jumps ... give a sense that the director is assembling a puzzle in which half the pieces are missing.
movie_title: Film Stars Don't Die in Liverpool (2017)

movie_review_blurb: In the Fade shows how the most devastating damage caused by terrorists sometimes isn't to those who die; it's to those who remain alive.

Naoko Yamada is regarded as one of the "up and coming" animated filmmakers seeking to fill the void created by the retirement of Hayao Miyazaki. Considering the artwork in A Silent Voice, it's easy to see why.
[Javier] Fuentes-Leon's little gem is unpolished and rough around the edges but it shines brightly enough to be worth a couple hours' viewing time.
I didn't hate it the way I often do January movies. And that's the nicest thing I can say about it.
This is one sequel it's a pleasure to review.
Although the characters are all types, the performances are strong enough that we identify with them despite their lack of depth.
Den of Thieves delivers an above-average cops-and-robbers heist film.
Rarely can I remember a movie filled with so many miraculous rescues and associated contrivances.
The movie plods and meanders through an overly-familiar narrative on its way to a half-baked and uneven conclusion.
Braven is a standard-order action/thriller with adequate performances, occasional bursts of tension, awful dialogue, and a minimal narrative.
Of the four Insidious films, only one has been any good and, although The Last Key may not be the worst of them, it's easily the most irrelevant and generic.
A distinct snapshot not only of the main character but of the setting that resulted in his becoming historically important.

Baumbach sketches out the intra-family conflicts with aptitude, making sure there's enough lightness to avoid a spiral into the kind of grim and humorless affair the French are fond of, but there's an element of familiarity to the overall narrative arc.
It's well-made, nicely paced and accomplishes what we expect from this sort of film.
Unfortunately, the jokes stop being funny about 30 minutes before the end credits roll and the character-based elements are never better than overly familiar.
Headlined by a committed Charlize Theron, Atomic Blonde offers the kind of kick-ass female action hero the non-superhero side of the genre could use more of.
At its best, this seems like a second-rate version of Pixar's Inside Out. At its worst, it's a cash-grab based on a cynical high-level concept.
Detroit is so effective at what it does and how it accomplishes its aims that it becomes almost unwatchable.
Superficial, uninspired, and forgettable.
Unfortunately, although there's an opportunity here to do something compelling, that opportunity is largely wasted.
The only way Kidnap could possibly work is if the viewer isn't paying attention.
Eye-opening and humanizing, the film focuses not on the Japanese war machine but the innocent peasants who bore the brunt of what their government unleashed.
movie_title: In This Corner of the World (Kono sekai no katasumi ni) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Brigsby Bear can be accused of a lot of things, but lack of ambition isn't among them.

Lambert's three-dimensionality elevates Wind River above the norms of the traditional crime movie so that, in addition to delivering the expected tropes, it provides a richer, more fulfilling experience.
By laminating Walls' story with a Hollywood sheen, the narrative climaxes in an artificial and contrived manner.
This is a feel-good tale through-and-through yet, because of the aesthetic and setting, it doesn't feel cloying and artificial.
The disappointment of what What Happened to Monday could have been dogs this movie as it navigates safe, predictable roads through an unsurprising twist to a preordained ending.
6 Days works not only as a portal into what happened 37 years ago but as an understanding of the difficulties of handling hostage situations and why it's easy for things to go very wrong.
We haven't had much of an opportunity to see Nikolaj Coster-Waldau flexing his acting chops in other roles. Shot Caller gives us an inkling of what he's capable of.
As a complete motion picture experience, it falls considerably short.
movie_title: Valerian and the City of a Thousand Planets (2017)

movie_review_blurb: I found myself wishing that Robespierre had uncovered something more interesting for her characters to do than act out plotlines from other movies I had already seen.
The only thing that keeps us from tuning out is that it's a pleasure to watch the actors exchange dialogue. Is that a good enough reason to see a movie? Depends what you're looking for.
This accomplished, exceptional piece of cinema delivers summer-scale spectacle, albeit without the escapism audiences often crave from blockbuster releases at this time of the year.
I'm hard-pressed to think of a recent movie that's as uncomfortable and disturbing as It Comes at Night.
My Cousin Rachel is a study in perception and perspective, a story that features a firm resolution while leaving its most compelling questions unanswered.
An overwrought, tonally inconsistent drama about cancer, death, and child abuse.
This is a real movie about real people doing real things and facing real problems.
Some of the best jokes are belly busters. My favorite involves a slow car and a speed bump.
The final chapter of the trilogy has saved the best for last and will at least deflect the most serious concerns of those who think this series has taken too many extra laps.
Distilled to its essence, The Last Knight is an orgy of incoherence, a sensory assault that suffocates the viewer in a cavalcade of special effects incontinence.
For me, The Hitman's Bodyguard is the epitome of what a summer movie should be.

Wright is savvy enough to realize that suspense and tension require characters that are more than human figures in a CGI playground. He does just enough with the men and women populating Baby Driver for us to get a sense of who they are.
The movie contains some tremendous individual scenes but the whole isn't better than the sum of its parts and, in the final analysis, it's a little disappointing.
A near-miss that offers a captivating atmosphere and strong performances to go along with an uneven tone and a climax that's so overcooked that it bursts at the seams with unintentional humor.
It's a perfectly reasonable option for a family movie outing and isn't so bad that adults will cringe.
The movie lacks inspiration; even the big "twist" is more worthy of a suppressed chuckle than a dropped jaw - it's like something pulled out of a bad soap opera.
It's funny, touching, and perceptive.

War for the Planet of the Apes bucks the trend of late-franchise films as creatively bankrupt cash grabs. This is a vital, original, and emotionally potent chapter to one of the longest-running movie series out there.
movie_title: War for the Planet of the Apes (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Lost in Paris is occasionally self-indulgent, although one could argue that's part of its charm.
This movie takes all sorts of chances and, for the most part, scores big.

The bare necessities are there, the performances are competent, and there are some strong moments but Race suffers from a lack of ambition. It's too safe and that quality mutes its impact and limits its ability to be more than a history lesson.
It's good to have Soderbergh back, even if he never was really away.
Bushwick never achieves what it sets out to do. It's undone by a litany of bad decisions and the underlying weakness of the core material.
Polina is mesmerizing.
American Made is breezy and fun and makes its points without subjecting the viewer to a browbeating.
Frears hasn't just made an historical recreation; he has made a movie containing a message with universal implications for all places and times when racism rears its head.
Liam Neeson is excellent. Regardless of whether he accurately embodies the real Mark Felt, he fulfills the role we expect from Deep Throat - a crusader who won't back down.
movie_title: Mark Felt: The Man Who Brought Down the White House (2017)

movie_review_blurb: About halfway through Battle of the Sexes, I found myself wishing I was watching a documentary rather than a feature film.
One of the year's best science fiction titles.
What we get is a mediocre remake of a mediocre original - not exactly must-see cinema.
Blade Runner 2049 honors the original in many ways - some small and some large - but it's not a soft reboot. It's a new story with new ideas and new purpose.
As far as it goes, the first film is an enjoyable space opera but, as a stand-alone, it doesn't work.
movie_title: The Osiris Child: Science Fiction Volume One (2017)

movie_review_blurb: The Florida Project achieves something rare and magical: presenting existence from the perspective of a young child while, at the same time, providing enough "clues" that viewers are able to decipher what's really going on.
It's hard to imagine a more generic wilderness adventure-turned-romance than Hany Abu-Assad's The Mountain Between Us.
6 Below suffers from a charisma deficit.
Director Lucky McKee and screenwriters Jared Butler and Lars Norberg take a standard premise and tweak it sufficiently to make it interesting and, at times, even darkly humorous.
Rebecca Hall gives a standout performance - something so good that it's worth remembering when end-of-the-year citations are issued.
Happy Death Day is about 90 minutes long and, past the first half-hour, every minute is dumber than the one before it.
As a feel good dramatic comedy, The Tiger Hunter hits most of the right notes while only sounding a few sour ones.
Although the pacing is uneven, the end result satisfies. The movie may be marketed to art house audiences but it has something to say to (and about) us all.

Tatiana Maslany, known for playing multiple roles in the cult TV series Orphan Black, invests Erin with a wealth of complexity in playing a character who wants desperately to do the right thing but who is pushed to the breaking point.
At its best, it recycles elements from The LEGO Movie in ways that feel cheap and redundant. At its worst, it's a tedious bore.
Ghost House is a classic "your mileage may vary" film. Horror lovers who are just looking for a few good scares and a suitably creepy atmosphere will find that Ragsdale delivers.
England is Mine is watchable but not special and those with the strongest interest in the story may be unhappy about what's missing.

Problems aside, it's refreshing to stumble on a film of this genre that doesn't fall under the "standard order horror" umbrella where an avalanche of jump scares replaces attempts to generate a pervasive sense of unease.
An unpleasant, unwatchable example of why people no longer love romantic comedies.
In addition to regurgitating parts of Goon, Goon: Last of the Enforcers pilfers liberally from Rocky 3 and Rocky 4.
Like many complex novels crammed into 100-page screenplays, Tulip Fever is a mess of too many subplots, all awkwardly condensed and fighting for screen time.
What is it about clowns, anyway?

Ingrid Goes West is part comedy, part tragedy, part horror/thriller, and part social commentary. Although it is primarily satirical, director/co-writer Matt Spicer never loses sight of the characters.
A Victorian-era gothic stew that, although perhaps not as ultimately satisfying as it might have been, nevertheless provides for an unsettling two hours.
Whatever small pleasures it may offer are wiped out by the frustrating sense of incompleteness that accompanies the arrival of the end credits.
Artificial and reeking of white privilege, this is the kind of movie that causes regular folks to shake their heads and mutter things about "entitlement" when speaking of the "Hollywood elite."
I've seen dozens of movies about weddings and this is among the most enjoyable two or three; its unpretentiousness is infectious.
The film offers little more depth about the writer than his Wikipedia article and considerably less than one would get from reading the semi-autobiographical The Catcher in the Rye.
It's too bad it doesn't work.
American Assassin is as generic an espionage thriller as you're likely to find.
Although there are individual moments that snap, crackle, and pop, the production as a whole is bloated and at times even a little tedious.
Quibbles aside, the movie is consistently involving because it invites the viewer to explore the implications of this technological breakthrough alongside the main character.
From a distance, Lethal Weapon might appear generic, but a closer look reveals something special.
I would prefer seeing a failed attempt at something different than a regurgitation of every modern horror trope. Yet The Witch proves unable to capitalize on being different.
A horrifically bad romantic comedy that serves as a celebration of entitlement, consumerism, and shallow behavior.
Phil Lord and Christopher Miller's second-best film of the year (behind The Lego Movie).
Jersey Boys comes to life only toward the end.
This is as excruciating a movie as is likely to be experienced by anyone, anywhere.
This is a uniquely powerful motion picture, the kind of open and honest portrayal I can't ever recall having seen about a celebrity.
It's often said for films of this sort that it's the journey that matters, not the destination. Unfortunately, in this case, neither is worth the price of admission.
First, the script is dumb.
This installment inches events closer to a merge point with 1968's Planet of the Apes while maintaining its own unique identity. It is in every way superior to Rise of the Planet of the Apes.
movie_title: Dawn Of The Planet Of The Apes (2014)

movie_review_blurb: It is better than the first film in almost every way but that doesn't mean it's appreciably smarter or has appeal to those who like meat on their action-oriented bones.
Yes, there are some laughs, but they're not as big or as frequent as one might expect from a would-be "major" comedy.
A sci-fi yarn that ponders the meaning of time and the importance of evolution while occasionally throwing in some shootouts.

A big-budget misfire of a sizeable order, a visually busy but emotionally dead endeavor that wearies the viewer with endless computer generated special effects while failing to provide a scintilla of human interest.
Everything about the movie is as uninspired as the title.
Big ideas can sometimes lead to great motion pictures or, as in the case of I Origins, colossal misfires.
Just another unmemorable motion picture for which it's difficult to remember the broad brush strokes, not to mention the details, once the house lights have come on.
Guardians of the Galaxy is solid summer fun - not the mammoth epic we have come to expect from each new Marvel release, but a welcome entry into a moribund movie season.
There's something welcome about a motion picture that doesn't hand out a dumbed-down resolution in a neatly wrapped package.
Whatever failings the film may have, none can be laid at the feet of lead actor Chadwick Boseman, whose performance is phenomenal.

Although there are times when bits of the movie feel extraneous, the production as a whole comes across more like an organic extension of the original tale than something tacked on purely to score at the box office.
Edge of Tomorrow is clever enough that the viewer doesn't have to feel embarrassed sitting in the audience but not so clever that there's no fun to be had.
movie_title: Live Die Repeat: Edge of Tomorrow (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Unfortunately, it takes more than grand concepts to make a movie and the lack of cinematic connective tissue is apparent in this poorly focused, meandering, and ultimately disappointing film.
The "nature" aspects of Bears are undercut by the need to turn this into a live-action Disney cartoon, complete with cuddly heroes and nasty villains.
A D-grade action flick with nothing to recommend it beyond a cacophony of mind-numbingly generic action sequences ...
Has it come to this for director Nick Cassavetes?
An undercooked cinematic casserole that blends some genuinely touching moments and well-presented action sequences with bad melodrama, overlong exposition, and overexposed CGI.
A slight movie but enjoyable nevertheless even if its brevity hints at something that, given more time to breathe, could have been a richer, more rewarding experience.
With tremendous work by actor Tom Hardy anchoring a film that is ripe with dramatic tension, Locke is entirely absorbing despite the limitations imposed by the setting.

There's no doubt the filmmakers want to make us laugh but, in doing so, they also touch upon a theme that many older viewers will find familiar: the rite of passage from a college party animal to the responsible role of a father or mother.
This may not exactly be the Godzilla I grew up with but it's a more than acceptable upgrade.
A slice-of-life story that does a good job italicizing how little moments in the big scheme of things can seem like monumental disasters while one is in high school.
Sappy, saccharine, and predictable to the point where it's almost painful.
For those who felt The Last Stand was a poor exit for many of these characters, X-Men: Days of Future Past should at least salve the wound in part.
What's missing from Blended? Two key ingredients: it doesn't touch the heart and it doesn't tickle the funny bone (at least not often enough).
Angelina Jolie's interpretation of the title character, which transforms the animated icon into a complex, fully realized woman, provides emotional depth and breadth.
A Million Ways to Die in the West feels like about 80 minutes of material was padded out to 110 minutes.
movie_title: A Million Ways to Die in the West (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Calling The Fault in Our Stars a "teenage cancer romance" might be understating the film's laudable qualities but it's also a reasonably accurate three-word summary of the plot.

The Hundred-Foot Journey is vintage Hallstrom - genial and meditative, focusing more on characters and emotions than an overcooked plot. The story is simple; the people inhabiting the movie make this worth seeing.
Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles doesn't so much provide brainless enjoyment as it pummels the viewer into submission. "Shell-shocked" is a reasonable description of the experience.
An exceptionally well-crafted coming-of-age story.
145 minutes of riveting drama and surprises.
Not only is this an amateurish travesty combining fundamentalist Christian eschatology with disaster movie b.s., but it's plodding and tedious.
Jeremy Renner hasn't been this good since The Hurt Locker (although most of his output since then has been in popcorn movies - hey, the guy needs to make a living).
Simultaneously touching and funny while being relevant to current events and respectful of the issues involved.
An overlong crowd-pleaser that mistakes a hackneyed catharsis for something more meaningful.
A generic vampire tale in the Underworld vein that comes closer to the infamous Van Helsing than a memorable re-interpretation of a legendary monster.
These characters are extremes but Reitman employs them in this microcosm to dramatic (and sometimes darkly comedic) purposes.
The Book of Life moves breezily from one scene to the next, keeping the pace brisk and rarely skipping a beat.
Murray, with a stable of eccentric characters ranging across the landscape of his career, has selected increasingly idiosyncratic roles in recent years. Vincent is no exception.
Inarritu unquestionably has an ax to grind and he has honed the edge.
This is an intense movie, with taut, expertly depicted tank battles and a believable sense of camaraderie among the characters.
John Wick is a rousing action thriller of the sort rarely encountered in theaters these days.

At times, it evidences the qualities of a can't-turn-away car wreck: brutal and horrific yet compelling. At other times, it has the rhythms of a sports drama with all the ups and downs inherent in that genre.
There's a sense that The Good Lie wants to say something profound but the message is as muddled as its delineation of history is.
Were it not for the participation of two A-list actors, Nicole Kidman and Colin Firth, Before I Go to Sleep would have been headed straight to video.
While there's limited value in Hector's search for happiness and the dozen-plus "lessons" he learns about the emotional state, the film works nicely as a character piece.
movie_title: Hector And The Search For Happiness (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Good People provides the degree of entertainment one expects while sitting on a sofa watching a direct-to-video effort rather than the higher standards one sets for paying $10 for a movie ticket.
The Boxtrolls represents the best animated movie to reach theater screens since The Lego Movie exploded on the scene in February.
Fuqua infuses The Equalizer with a low-key energy and is in no hurry to rush into things.
It feels familiar and the appeal of the leads can't fully compensate for unremarkable dialogue and the obligatory (but nevertheless irritating) "romantic complications" subplot.
The destruction and carnage is presented with verve and flair, making this a fine example of tornado porn.
In the ranks of dystopian YA-targeted motion pictures, this one can stand alongside its peers.
For a variety of reasons, most having to do with a weak screenplay and poor pacing, The Expendables 3 is the least successful entry in the series.
It's a tease: worthwhile in some ways but ultimately too diluted to offer a fulfilling movie-going experience.
The acting is solid across the breadth of the cast, with all the actors fitting nicely into their roles. Mortez is especially good; she brings humanity and believability to Mia.
For those who appreciated Robert Rodriguez and Frank Miller's 2005 campy, kinetic film noir homage, Sin City, the 2014 follow-up, Sin City: A Dame to Kill For is unlikely to disappoint.
movie_title: Frank Miller's Sin City: A Dame to Kill For (2014)

movie_review_blurb: For a horror movie, Oculus is surprisingly lean on the scares. It's more interested in playing tricks with perception and bending reality.
When the Game Stands Tall is one of those cliché-riddled feel good movies that, by trying too hard to be inspirational, ends up as cloying and overly sentimental.
There's nothing terribly wrong with The November Man in a serviceable late-night cable TV sort of way but neither is there anything terribly right about it. It's unnecessary and derivative.
This short and simple film is beautiful not only in its emotionally-honest story but in its cinematography.
The Drop's unpredictability is organic rather than sensationalistic. The movie doesn't pull surprises out of thin air for the sole purpose of shocking an audience - it lets them develop naturally.
The performances are uniformly strong and there are some powerful scenes but the overall story arc is less insightful or affecting than one might hope.
movie_title: The Disappearance of Eleanor Rigby: Them (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Despite a strong opening and riveting first 45 minutes, The Maze Runner devolves into one of the weakest post-apocalyptic Young Adult movies to reach theaters in recent years.
It's easy to be impressed by the dramatic capabilities of actors known primarily for lighter fare - in particular, Jason Bateman and Tina Fey, both of whom are terrific.
movie_title: This Is Where I Leave You (2014)

movie_review_blurb: If this is your kind of movie, it's hard to find one better made.

It's weird and surreal, but it ends with most of the holes plugged and all but a few of the loose ends tied into a tidy package. Some argue this is a cheat and the film should have been more open ended. That's a personal choice; I like it the way it is.
This isn't fun, escapist entertainment but, when it works, it's fascinating and compelling and makes us take a hard look at what TV news is selling and where it's getting the product.
It ends up feeling a little like warmed-over Strictly Ballroom without Baz Lurhmann's over-the-top sense of style.
When one looks deeply enough, this is as much about the personalities of the characters as it is about the trades they're involved in.
A misfire in far too many meaningful aspects, The Book Thief is so bad that it's tough to decide whether it's better used as a sleep aid or watched while under the influence as an object of derision.
Offers its audience many of the elements that made The Hunger Games compelling, but adds to that by deepening the themes and emotional currents and traveling to darker destinations.
Calling Delivery Man a "comedy" is a bit of a stretch, because it's rarely funny. Dumb, yes, but not in a way that's worthy of more than a half-hearted chuckle.
Sad? At times. But also very, very funny in other instances.
It's simple and well-told, although nothing about it is breathtakingly original.
It's almost impossible not to like the film if you grew up consuming Disney animation.
There's something almost refreshing about a movie that delivers exactly what's expected of it.
Sometimes I don't understand the Hollywood mindset. Who thought remaking Park Chan-wook's 2003 cult classic, Oldboy, was a good idea?

Features some nice performances and is deliciously atmospheric but it never achieves its goal of being a compelling meditation about how the economic erosion of a community influences the lives of those trapped within it.

This isn't a rags-to-riches story. There's no great moment of catharsis. In fact, the filmmakers openly flout mainstream expectations when they show a certain highway sign then proceed to ignore the location shown on it.
It's epic fantasy for those who thinks the term means monsters, chases, fights, and little else.
movie_title: The Hobbit: The Desolation of Smaug (2013)

movie_review_blurb: In spite of the subject matter's seediness (ABSCAM resulted in the corruption convictions of a U.S. senator, six members of the House of Representatives, and several lesser politicians), Russell's script is laced with wit.
At two hours, Anchorman 2 overstays its welcome by at least 20 minutes, if not longer.
The movie avoids commonplace traps; it never becomes maudlin and it doesn't transform Travers into a likeable elderly lady whose heart of gold is camouflaged by crotchetiness.
Scorsese presents Belfort as a charismatic Caligula. He is an endlessly fascinating character who holds viewers' attention from beginning to end.
The problem is that it doesn't aim particularly high and, when the tears have dried and the cheers have subsided, there's a sense that what the movie offers is disappointingly ephemeral.
It's hard to pinpoint the cause of the problem, but Walter's story never engages.
movie_title: The Secret Life Of Walter Mitty (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Thor is essentially Marvel's answer to Superman and, as with The Man of Steel, it can be difficult to craft a tale around a hero who is essentially invincible.
With more attention to detail, this could have worked, but the time travel aspects are so badly executed that the movie as a whole falters and eventually rips apart at the seams.
Wow.
Various subplots are given short shrift and the whole thing feels more like a Cliff's Notes version of a longer piece than an actual finished motion picture.
An intense experience that will leave many viewers exhausted by the time the 2 1/4-hour running time expires.
In a way, it's like the cover of a favorite pop tune - inferior, to be sure, but nevertheless pleasantly familiar.
Machete Kills plays like a joke that's been told a few times too often.
The material covered in the production's 128 minutes is not only inherently non-cinematic but not remotely "thrilling," at least in the conventional sense.
Hafstrom tries to pretend his stars are about 40 and, for the most part, it works.
Rather than fixing some of the problems with De Palma's approach and trying something fresh, Peirce compounds them.
The film offers a formidable indictment of the cruelty of which human beings are capable.
All is Lost is about how human nature rebels against death, even when all hope is vanquished by adverse circumstances.
It's not so much a bad film as it is a disappointing one. A very disappointing one.
It's an almost overpowering experience - a movie that transcends voyeurism and invites empathy.
Ender's Game is recognizable in tone, thematic content, and narrative progression as Card's vision.
The actors perform with multiple safety nets and the closest the film ever comes to taking a risk is having Freeman dance to a cover of Earth Wind & Fire's "September."
Sixteen years after her death, Princess Diana is still capable of generating interest, which is probably the only reason why this dull, pointless movie was greenlighted.
In many ways, the film is all about Matthew McConaughey, and Canadian director Jean-Marc Vallee is wise enough to train his focus on the actor.
The underlying premise of Grudge Match is appealing, even if the execution is lackluster.
Most war films try to be epic in scope and intent. Lone Survivor opts for a smaller focus and succeeds on its own terms.
Her uses a familiar idea to sci-fi fans - machine sentience - and spins it in a new and exciting direction.
The film has a nihilistic tone and its gallows humor may turn off more viewers than it seduces. Not since Killer Joe has a film exerted this mix of attraction and repulsion.
Nymphomaniac Volume I is possibly the best movie Lars von Trier has made since Dancer in the Dark.
It offers an engaging 90+ minutes of unconventional, comedy-tinged adventure that references numerous classic movies while developing a style and narrative approach all its own.
Veronica Mars is a delightful piece of fan service - a supersized TV reunion episode expanded for viewing in movie theaters.
This movie is a complete bore.
The film's problem is that, despite obvious aspirations to be more than just a profane joke factory, it never fulfills its dramatic ambitions.

Although not quite as well-focused as The Hunger Games, Divergent employs many of the same elements: a futuristic post-war setting, a strong heroine, a romance, and a struggle against the oppression inherent in the status quo.
[It] isn't as giddily entertaining as its predecessor but much of the charm remains, making this an ideal destination for a family excursion.
The performances are solid but I walked out of the theater thinking I might have been equally edified and entertained reading the man's Wikipedia entry.
Exhaustingly repetitive, this movie attempts many of the same things its predecessor did but with less success.

It's overlong and a times sluggish. The fights and battles, designed to give an epic fantasy feel to the movie, are grave miscalculations. And the overabundance of CGI often makes Noah look like a video game.
For most of its running length, Sabotage is a gritty, compelling motion picture with twists to make a pretzel envious. Unfortunately, it overstays its welcome.
This film is unlikely to convert a non-Captain America lover into a fanatic but it's assembled with sufficient skill that those who enjoy this sort of motion picture will have a good time.
It's as existential as a sci-fi/horror film can possibly be. It requires that the viewer slip into a meditative mood and remain there for more than 90 minutes.
This is an action junkie's fix and it literally pulls no punches.
The lack of a creative driver behind the film leads to a level of fundamental dissatisfaction. The movie delivers all the necessary elements but their impact is dull.
In terms of tone, visual beauty, and storytelling, The Wind Rises represents Miyazaki at the apex of his abilities.
Non-Stop plays like what might happen if Michael Bay directed a screenplay developed for Alfred Hitchcock.
How did 3 Days to Kill, which doesn't have the worst imaginable premise, turn out this bad?
August: Osage County is all about the acting. That makes sense because the storyline doesn't offer much that could be considered new or remarkable.
Ralph Fiennes, working from a screenplay by Abi Morgan, has brought this story to the screen in a film that will appeal greatly to Dickens enthusiasts and those who enjoy British costume dramas.
The core essentials that made the previous Jack Ryan movies accessible and enjoyable remain intact in Jack Ryan: Shadow Recruit, even if many of the individual pieces have changed.
At its best, Ride Along is tolerable. At its worst, it borders on insulting.
The questions posed by Like Father, Like Son are universal in nature and the manner in which Kore-eda addresses them makes for superior drama.
It's no fun. Everyone takes this way too seriously.
There are times when the blend of romance and raunchiness threatens to curdle. In the end, however, the "love conquers all" mentality wins out.
Dom Hemingway suffers from a meandering narrative and inconsistent comedy.
"Labor" isn't just a word in the title of Jason Reitman's new film, it's a description of what it feels like to sit through the movie.
The movie does a good job of illustrating why protecting art from the Nazi scourge was important but it's far less effective fleshing out the personalities of the people who did the protecting.
This is truly a movie that children and their parents can both enjoy for different reasons.
It retains the central ideas and themes of the original while updating and rearranging the narrative to lose a derivative feel.

About Last Night takes us through the Honeymoon Phase and into the difficult realm beyond. That's where couples have to work to stay together, and that's where this movie gains its strongest traction.
On a purely narrative level, Winter's Tale missteps early and often. Its earnestness is its downfall, resulting in opportunities for unintentional humor.
An effective period piece thriller that incorporates love, lust, desperation, and madness into a stew thickened by a gothic atmosphere.
Pompeii is a big, glorious, cheesy mess.
Kids for Cash provides a clear, balanced narrative, opening with campaign ads and footage of Ciavarella giving a "tough talk" presentation at a Scranton school.

It's an amazing achievement that deserves to be seen on the biggest screen with the best sound system possible. Nolan has crafted Interstellar as a movie theater experience. Watching it at home, no matter how good the sound system is, won't match.

The screenplay is smart enough to be considered adult-friendly. This isn't "classic Disney" but it's an experience parents and children can enjoy together in the dark, and sometimes that's all one can ask of a big-budget animated film.
Shelton opts for a simple shooting style that emphasizes relationships and dialogue rather than trying to call attention to the filmmaker's talent.
As misfires go, American Ultra can at least claim not to be boring.
Although Sinister 2 continues the story begun in Scott Derrickson's creepily effective Sinister, it feels more like an unnecessary retread than an organic extension of the original.
This isn't lightweight, fanciful entertainment; it's tense, white-knuckle material.
Despite clocking in at a skinny 84 minutes, Mistress America overstays its welcome.
If you find yourself in an auditorium watching We Are Your Friends, there's no need to get up and leave. On the other hand, there's no compelling reason to be put in that position in the first place.
A Walk in the Woods is pleasant but inconsequential, a passing diversion rather than a worthy cinematic destination.
Despite a promising premise and effective "Shyamalan twist", this low-budget horror film still underwhelms.
For Black Mass, Johnny Depp has dusted off his A-game, which has lain dormant for far too long.
With minimal plot development and far too much running around in dark corridors, The Scorch Trials has a poor story:filler ratio. And much of what happens is poorly thought-out.

Everest takes an inordinate amount of time to get the pieces in place. However, once the group departs base camp and begins the ascent, the film sloughs off its slow pace and transforms into a gripping tale of survival, life, and death.
In terms of comedic and dramatic content, The Intern is hit-and-miss. Notions about ageism and corporate prejudice against female CEOs are grazed but not explored in a meaningful or compelling way.
This is science fiction for sophisticated audiences and, as such, a fulfilling and satisfying experience.
An unforgettable motion picture that should be on the must-see list for anyone who appreciates films that deal in grays rather than blacks and whites.

It's two-thirds of a great film but the slow start and unremarkable first hour hold it back. Still, for those who buy into the precept that "good things are worth waiting for," The Walk unquestionably delivers.
The film fulfills its limited mandate of providing fast-paced adventure and some nice eye candy without adding anything memorable to the tale of The Boy Who Can Fly.
Only a bare minimum of non-action scenes were included in the final cut. There's enough here to piece together a rudimentary storyline but the details are often either confusing or nonsensical.
In terms of the director's oeuvre, this will likely be remembered as one of his "minor" productions. (Think Always, The Terminal, and War Horse.)
Clever and atmospheric, the film has enough twists to keep the average viewer guessing.

The movie is mature in the way it handles the regrets of absentee parents and the ways in which their children relate to them. There's a little Hollywood artifice here but not so much that the emotions feel inauthentic.
The film's brevity makes it easily digestible but there's an underlying sense of frustration - dissatisfaction that the characters aren't fleshed out better and the humor isn't more organic.

It counterbalances sentimentality with a dose of cynicism and, although the film's second half is considerably weaker than the first hour, it offers better entertainment than several big budget films clogging multiplex auditoriums.
The film fumbles its lame narrative and, although some of MacFarlane's jokes are hilarious, they're just blips on the radar.
Terminator Genisys feels like the film Cameron might have made if he continued the franchise.
Too many elements that made the first film an enjoyable experience are missing.
Self/less begins with a promising (albeit well-worn) science fiction premise, degrades it by turning it into a generic thriller, and finishes it off with a rushed, disjointed ending.
Inconsistent and undisciplined, Minions is more an adjunct to marketing than a legitimate motion picture.

The attempts at overt comedy are hit-and-miss. The heist elements are derivative and not nearly as inventive as one might expect given the possibilities. The action sequences are variable and the dramatic moments... the less said, the better.
Trainwreck is brash, funny, and often vulgar.
Paper Towns is an exercise in artifice.
This is a film in which a viewer can be forgiven for rooting for the old video game icons to annihilate humanity. God help us if the best savior we can muster is Sandler.
Southpaw isn't content with presenting a gallery of clichéd characters. It takes the time to put flesh on the bones.
Vacation passes the most important test of any comedy: it's funny.
Hopefully, the reception will be positive because, on the strength of this outing, a sixth big-screen impossible mission is warranted.
There are hints of a more compelling story but they are never developed and the movie as a whole seems like the unhappy marriage of competing agendas.
This is one of those rare instances when a sequel wouldn't just be warranted - it would be welcomed.
The dialogue crackles with wit, anger, and passion. By matching Sorkin's words with Boyle's style and Fassbender's talent, Steve Jobs has hit the trifecta.
At a guess, I'd say that Goosebumps will satisfy its core audience - fans of R.L. Stine's popular children's books - and bore pretty much everyone else.
Director Guillermo del Toro's unique visual style is on display but the story is predictable, the characters are flat, and the supernatural elements are red herrings.
Best film of the year? Yes.

The Revenant isn't for everyone - it asks more from its audience than the average motion picture - but for those to whom the subject matter appeals, it will be among 2015's most memorable theatrical options.
Concussion's dramatic core is solid and its unwillingness to sugarcoat the NFL's tactics is likely to raise some eyebrows.
Joy can be viewed as a modern day rags-to-riches fairytale. It's Cinderella without the prince. In a way, that's part of the film's charm.
Analyzed on its own merits or in concert with the earlier film, Point Break doesn't work.
The Forest boasts a promising premise but squanders most of its goodwill as a result of narrative shortcuts and contrivances, horror film clichés, and haphazard editing.
Anomalisa offers evidence that animated films are not necessarily the sole province of children. In fact, this one isn't even designed for all adults.
The movie is imperfect and overlong but it's never boring. And, although aspects of its factual accuracy can be called into question, it does a decent job of chronicling what happened that night.
movie_title: 13 Hours: The Secret Soldiers Of Benghazi (2016)

movie_review_blurb: The storyline is generic apocalyptic science fiction and feels a lot like an uninspired fusion of Independence Day and the TV mini-series "V".
There are numerous powerful Holocaust movies available but I don't think I've ever seen anything that offers the kind of grim, you-are-there perspective of Son of Saul.
The Finest Hours is all about action, suspense, and tension, and it rarely lets its audience down on any of those accounts.
Kids, especially those who enjoyed the previous Kung Fu Panda movies, will appreciate what the third movie has to offer.
The more 1950s movies a person has seen and the greater their love for Hollywood of 60+ years ago, the greater their appreciation will be of what Joel and Ethan have brought to the screen.
The bottom line is that Burr Steers' adaptation is unlikely to please any audience regardless of what they're looking for.
This is a different kind of movie. The only rule it adheres to is that tropes are made to be eviscerated, turned on their heads, and trampled over.

Against all odds, The Big Short works. In fact, "works" is an understatement for what director Adam McKay has achieved with his improbable adaptation of Michael Lewis' nonfiction book about the 2008 global financial crisis.
Watching Youth, you'd swear Fellini had risen from his grave and returned to make another movie.
It's a solid space opera spectacle with enough nostalgia to overpower even the most hard-hearted child of the '70s and '80s but it relies a little too much on recycling old plot elements.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode VII - The Force Awakens (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Visually and viscerally, the film provides reasons to pay the price of admission and see it in a theater.
movie_title: In the Heart of the Sea (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Unfortunately, a film needs more than Diesel's Stallone-ish appeal to succeed and that's where The Last Witch Hunter is found lacking.
From a historical perspective, Suffragette is riddled with inaccuracies, but that's less of a problem than its questionable dramatic arc.
Room is honest and challenging but it's more uplifting than one might expect from a film with such a horrific backstory.
The movie is funny enough to get its share of laughs but, in its angry heart, it's a tragedy - and the saddest part is that too much of this story is true.
To those with even a limited exposure to Peanuts over the years, this will feel like a homecoming. Is that a bad thing? No, but it's more of a trip down memory lane than something new.
In the end, this solid Bond does justice to the character's long legacy while paying due diligence to what he has become under Daniel Craig's stewardship.

In trying to breathe life into too many characters, the screenplay transforms them all into thinly-drawn caricatures. In focusing on its feel-good, inspirational ending, it fails to make nearly 2 hours of hardship a worthwhile experience.
The film's ability to confound expectations while delivering some big laughs may be its most crowd-pleasing characteristic but the anti-stereotype message rings clear as a bell throughout.
If there was a Best Ensemble acting category, the cast of Spotlight would be a frontrunner. The film has no lead actor but there are five or six strong supporting performances.
Although not without moments of sadness and tragedy, Brooklyn is sublimely uplifting and life affirming.
2015 has seen its share of sequels; perhaps surprisingly, Creed is among the best.
If The Good Dinosaur falls short in the narrative department, it represents a step forward for Pixar's artists.
To avoid the accusation that it's an unnecessary remake of an oft-told story, screenwriter Max Landis has reduced Mary Shelly's cautionary tale to a bad comic book, bereft of soul and intelligence.
Legend seems like a movie Scorsese might have made if he wasn't paying attention - the elements are present but they are clumsily assembled and the outcome underwhelms.
Carol is a haunting motion picture - the kind of film that stays with the viewer long after the multiplex's neon signage has disappeared from the rear-view mirror.

Watching The Danish Girl, it's possible to get some feeling for the deep sense of self-alienation a transgendered person can experience but the movie's aloof tone creates distance between the viewer and the lead characters.
The Hunger Games movies began with much promise but after the pinnacle of Catching Fire, it has been a slog to the finish line. We're finally there and I feel more exhausted than fulfilled.
Inside Out is the best American-produced animated film we have seen in many summers and deserves to be recognized as such.
Affecting without being overly sentimental, humorous without being inappropriately comedic, and quirky without being self-indulgent.
movie_title: Me and Earl and the Dying Girl (2015)

movie_review_blurb: A nice little gem for anyone intrigued by the concept of having fun with a giant of 19th century literature.
Taken 3 is exactly what one might anticipate from an unnecessary sequel in a mediocre franchise.
Despite being overlong, Blackhat is mostly engaging.
The Wedding Ringer is imperfect but its imperfections are tolerable because they're accompanied by a dollop of drama, a measure of laughter, and an oversized helping of Kevin Hart.
Spare Parts tries too hard to be a based-on-a-true-story, feel-good, crowd-pleasing, triumph-of-the-underdogs movie.
Still Alice is heartbreaking but it doesn't earn its tears through easy emotional manipulation.
At 150 minutes, it's a little too long but there are stretches during its course when it captivates and amazes.
It's badly directed, poorly edited, and features some of the most unconvincing acting this side of a soup commercial.
This isn't a revolutionary or thematically rich motion picture, but it's a well-told story featuring solid performances and a nice sense of atmosphere.
The film is by no means perfect and its goals are undermined by a sloppy climax and conclusion but it avoids preaching while providing fodder for thought.
The Cold War flavor gives Black Sea the feel of something that might have been made three decades ago.
Maybe it will work better on home video where unrestrained camera movement is less likely to provoke nausea but it certainly doesn't work on a big screen.

Jupiter Ascending feels like a truncated, Cliffs Notes version of something that might have worked a lot better as a mini-series. Two hours is too short for this tale and the end result suffers greatly because of that restriction.

Impressive set design and visuals, excessive CGI, and a loud score from Marco Beltrami can't fully compensate for bland character development and a predictable narrative that rushes along on a linear trajectory.
Who would have imagined that a movie about sex could be so boring?
Based on a comic book, Kingsman occasionally betrays its roots but Vaughn has adapted it to fit his unique approach.
The movie is riveting. It reminds us not only of how far we have come as a society but how far we have yet to go.
Predestination is science fiction for a thoughtful crowd.
The Gambler is a solid remake - a film that retraces the path of the original while carving out its own identity.
A straightforward and mature film with little in the way of overt weirdness.
An unremarkable bio-pic about a remarkable man.
The lengthy gestation period hasn't resulted in an appreciably upgraded experience.
Foxcatcher isn't afraid of venturing into territory avoided by most sports-related motion pictures. This isn't an inspirational film; in fact, quite the opposite is true.
This is Jon Stewart's directorial debut; the talk show comedian has a handle on the material and conveys it clearly.
This is as grim as PG-13 can get; the darkness is comparable to that of The Empire Strikes Back.
Horrible Bosses 2 (emphasis on "horrible") is an apt title for this repugnant, unnecessary sequel.
Diplomacy will work for those who appreciate dialogue-based character films in which plot is of secondary importance.
McFarland USA has a distinction in that it's the rare sports movie directed by a woman. Caro's perspective is invaluable to the film's trajectory.
Wild attempts to show how getting back to basics can arrest the downward spiral of a life pulled out of orbit by the gravity of pernicious influences.
The best film of The Hobbit's three, this final installment is closer in quality to The Lord of the Rings than to its immediate predecessors.
movie_title: The Hobbit: The Battle of the Five Armies (2014)

movie_review_blurb: At first glance, Inherent Vice might seem to be a detective story. Look a little closer, however, and it becomes clear that this is Paul Thomas Anderson's idea of a comedy.
It's easy to see The Imitation Game as a triumph - after all, Turing accomplished what all the experts claimed was impossible - but it's equally apparent that underlying the triumph is a tragedy.
Most remakes are unnecessary but Annie is a bigger offender than many.
There's a lot to like about the movie. Its presentation is straightforward, chronicling Zamperini's amazing tale without flinching.
Into the Woods left me out in the cold.
American Sniper lifts director Clint Eastwood out of the doldrums that have plagued his last few films.
The screenplay (credited to four screenwriters) is a mess, the pacing is uneven, the acting is inconsistent, and the experience as a whole is a letdown.

There are some clever bits and the satire is at times scathing but, on the whole, moments of hilarity are like oases in a desert of tedium. When Zoolander 2 isn't funny, the silliness strains the viewer's patience.
The DUFF would make John Hughes smile.
It does enough things right to earn a recommendation, but there are misfires aplenty for those who care to look for them.
I'll admit the film held my attention but I left the theater unsatisfied, which I think will be a common reaction among those not within the demographic niche for which the production was mounted.
There's not much plot here and very little in the way of character development. Alice is defined by her disorder and the screenplay isn't interested in delving into her life and relationships.
There's hardly an area in which Hot Pursuit is not found lacking.
Andrew Mogel and Jarrad Paul, making their directorial debut, manage the difficult task of keeping the audience engaged even though both of the main characters are unlikable.
Mad Max: Fury Road delivers. There's no clearer or more succinct way to put it. 30 years after last appearing on the big screen, Max roars back with a vengeance.

A blend of lackluster comedy and lazy plotting, the film feels a lot like bad Hitchcock.

A delightful movie.

It's a worthy effort, and recommended viewing for those who have interest.

On balance, more of the movie works than doesn't, but this isn't 140 minutes of unqualified successes.

movie_review_blurb: Yet another in the seemingly endless line of stupid, generic thrillers that Hollywood foists upon the movie-going public.

Of Austen's novels, none is more beloved than this one, so it's good to see it once again brought to the screen with the pride which it deserves.

movie_title: Harry Potter and the Goblet of Fire (2005)

An engaging experience.

This film is unable to involve, entertain, or titillate. Basically, it stinks.

A charming movie that falls short of greatness, but is still worth a solid recommendation.
For those who don't mind a little laughter with their zombies (or perhaps it should be the other way around), this is an unusual source of entertainment.

A mixed bag, but at least it's interesting and almost never boring.

Almost good enough to earn a recommendation.

This is a dull, plodding, ultra-serious feature that has a lot more in common with a video game than a motion picture.

One of the best thrillers I have seen this year: tight, taut, and unpredictable.
An emotionally fulfilling experience.

The pacing is uneven, leading to a bumpy road where laughter and gore sometimes complement each other and sometimes are at odds. This makes Severance more of a mixed bag than an unqualified success.
The thrilling final hour is almost enough to make one forget how much of a labor it is to trudge through the first two-thirds -- almost, but not quite.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: At Worlds End (2007)

movie_review_blurb: After a well-constructed first act, the story becomes a little tiresome and repetitive and the characters, who are will defined to begin with, stray ever closer to the edge of overwrought one-dimensionality.
These days, it's almost impossible to find a gritty science fiction motion picture that doesn't owe at least a small debt to Blade Runner's visual style.

Apatow is clearly a romantic, even if there's a profane edge to his 'love conquers all' worldview. Other filmmakers embarking into the comedy minefield could learn a thing or two from him. He's two for two.
Mr. Brooks is a curious mix of the campy and the intelligent, of high concept and low psychology. In spite of these contradictions, or perhaps because of them, it works.
Planet of the Apes is one of those rare films whose historical impact outweighs its quality. It's a good film, but not a classic.
Overnight, Mad Max went from being a U.S. cult hero to a mainstream figure, and Mel Gibson's place in the firmament was secured.
Gracie is painless enough and, at times, even enjoyable. But it suffers from an overriding feeling that this would be better positioned as a made-for-TV feature.
I would classify Charlie Bartlett as a smart teen film. It's more ambitious and overall more successful than its '80s forebears even though the resemblance is unmistakable.
Another week, another disappointing summer sequel. So it goes...
One has to consider that the film's problems -- and they are numerous -- may be the product of the franchise's runaway popularity.
Lucky You isn't Hanson's best movie but it's a respectable effort and deserves more of a chance to be seen than the one it's getting.
Waitress is a pleasant dramatic comedy that overcomes its tonal inconsistencies by presenting an engaging lead character with whom its virtually impossible not to empathize.
Black Book possesses a taut, exciting script that throws surprises at the viewer on a regular basis.
As a movie, The Hoax isn't a fraud but it's not the real deal, either.

Upon reflection, it's not difficult to understand why The Reaping languished for so long on the shelves of Warner Brothers before being dumped into distribution. The film, despite attempts at edit-room reparation, is virtually unreleasable.
First Snow keeps audiences guessing - not necessarily about how the film will end but what path things will take to get there.

Depending on your point-of-view, this is either a nostalgic stroll through a cheesy slice of American pop culture or an attempt to provide a tongue-in-cheek reinvigoration of it. Most likely, it's a little of both.
This is a fine tale of families and secrets, and its seemingly cold exterior gives way to something unexpectedly warm and soft inside.
The filmmakers' belief that modern audiences will only respond to noisy, inarticulate endings dooms this movie to a last act that devalues, rather than elevates, it.
Smokin' Aces is Tarantino lite -- a vague and unsuccessful attempt to bring together a bunch of offbeat, unrelated characters in a situation where a bloody resolution is inescapable.

What would happen if a late-night, D-grade direct-to-cable thriller excised all of the raunchily enjoyable elements and managed to attract an A-list cast? The result might be shockingly like Perfect Stranger.
A nicely compact, tense thriller that loses a little of its punch as a result of a rushed, generic ending.
With Anthony Hopkins in the lead and a screenplay that was composed by writers not merely interested in fitting together a jigsaw puzzle of clichÃ (C)s, this movie is gruesomely engaging.

It's the kind of production that's pleasant to watch because it allows viewers to spend some time with believable characters who face 'regular' problems, but do so without becoming boring or overly familiar.
The result is a mature and challenging motion picture, and something that will stick with viewers after the screen has gone dark.
The Condemned is the latest action film from director Scott Wiper. It is also a noun describing those poor viewers who end up stuck in a theater showing this film.

The film fails to play by a consistent set of rules and, while it's possible to justify that endgame twist, that doesn't mean it's a good idea. Some viewers will feel cheated by what Next does, and it's hard to blame them.
I hope Jamie Kennedy has a huge fan base because I can't see anyone else paying hard-earned money to sit through this.
This movie wants to tickle the funny bone while telling a story that's worth telling. For the most part, [director] Wright achieves this aim.
Ocean's Thirteen is the first sequel of the summer of 2007 not to fall on its face. The film is better paced and more involving than Ocean's Twelve but perhaps not as well executed as Ocean's Eleven.

There's no snowball effect and the characters are too weakly drawn and acted for there to be any psychological dimension to their interaction. The ending of the first movie was unsettling; the conclusion of this one is unsatisfying.
Director Nick Cassavetes should be commended for the unflinching manner in which he tells the story -- it packs a punch, although it lingers too long to be truly unsettling.
It's possible to see a deeper level to what's on screen but, regardless of whether or not a viewer chooses to engage the film in that way, it's an effective piece of cinema.
After watching this film, you will believe that evil exists on earth. That the movie deals in truth and established facts makes it all the more disturbing.
As dysfunctional family movies go, this is one skip. It doesn't just run with the scissors, it falls on them.
With A Tale of Springtime and A Tale of Winter, Eric Rohmer has given us a pair of wonderful motion pictures... I wonder what Summer and Autumn will bring.
Is Borat the funniest comedy of the year? Almost certainly -- but what's the competition?
movie_title: Borat: Cultural Learnings of America for Make Benefit Glorious Nation of Kazakhstan (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Although Volver has a tendency to stray too far down tangential paths, it is ultimately satisfying.
It's better than 90% of the animated fare of the last few years. It's refreshing not to have to qualify the movie's appeal by appending the words, 'for the kids'.
The few good aspects of this farce are vastly outweighed by the bad.
Perfect entertainment for five-year olds and sheer torture for the unlucky parent(s) accompanying them to the theater.
movie_title: The Santa Clause 3: The Escape Clause (2006)

movie_review_blurb: It takes a great premise and runs with it, neither wasting opportunities nor going off on tangents. It features strong work from both the main and supporting actors, and manages seamlessly to incorporate both humor and poignancy.
Few individuals who go off to war and experience its devastation and chaos return as the same person. This factor lies at the heart of what Harsh Times illustrates.

I have nothing against historical fiction: books or movies using real characters in situations that didn't happen. However, one would hope in such cases that the authors would have a story worth telling.
For those who don't mind pictures that fall into predictable rhythms, A Good Year represents a pleasant diversion.
Fur's misstep, and it is significant, is in the creature design of Lionel. The resemblance to Chewbacca is uncanny. He also looks a little like Lon Chaney's Wolf Man.
movie_title: Fur: An Imaginary Portrait of Diane Arbus (2006)

movie_review_blurb: In the movie business, there's no such thing as 'truth in titling.' If there was, Bobby would be called A Bunch of Boring, No-Name, Cookie-Cutter Characters.
Death of a President is celluloid mediocrity. It's neither interesting nor convincing.
One leaves the theater certain what Linklater's theme was but uncertain why it was presented so ineffectively.
Its complex (yet not mystifying) storytelling, forceful character development, and superb cinematography make this a candidate for one of 2006's best offerings.
This is a movie that never gets to the point, perhaps because it doesn't recognize what the point is.

Take a little of An Officer and a Gentleman and a little Top Gun and throw in some waves and underwater sequences, and you have The Guardian -- only with less charismatic actors, more tame sex scenes, and a lot less energy.
A Guide to Recognizing Your Saints illustrates that it's still possible to do something interesting with a familiar premise.
movie_title: A Guide to Recognizing Your Saints (2006)

movie_review_blurb: School for Scoundrels feels like a wasted opportunity.

The original film was gritty and entertaining; the new version is a masterpiece -- the best effort Scorsese has brought to the screen since Goodfellas.

Mitchell has stated that his goal with Shortbus was to make a serious film that incorporates hardcore material. To an extent, he has done that. The problem is it's not a good movie.
The Queen is an interesting character study. There's not much plot to speak of, but it gives actors (including a splendid Helen Mirren) an opportunity to shine.
Both disturbing and enlightening.

Whether we actually 'know' these individuals or not is beside the point; we feel we do, and this enriches the experience of watching the most ambitious documentary project ever committed to celluloid.
Capote was at times cool and antiseptic, but Infamous is warmer and more emotionally satisfying.

What we get, sadly, is easily the worst production Gilliam has ever been involved in, either behind the camera or in front of it. Tideland is, by turns, a complete bore and a creepy experience. And I don't mean 'creepy' in a positive sense.
Man of the Year makes telling points and has a lot to say, but it loses its voice along with its consistency around the mid-way point, and that will likely make it an also-ran in the box office race.

At its best, Flags of Our Fathers is eye opening and though provoking.
Watching The Prestige is like observing a magic act where the magician's sleight-of-hand isn't deft enough. The trick almost works, but not quite.
Despite being well made and supremely acted, Candy is a true feel-bad experience.
The ingredients for greatness are there. It's too bad the movie lost its way on the approach to the finish line. I recommend Happy Feet, but not as enthusiastically as I wish I could.
For Your Consideration will not go down as one of Guest's crown jewels, but it's nevertheless engaging.
The movie achieves a rare balance for an historical fiction: making use of the backdrop without allowing it to overwhelm the characters and their story.
The Good Shepherd is equally fascinating as a character drama and as a cold war thriller.
Although Eastwood does an adequate job of developing the characters into more than paper-thin soldiers, this isn't a character-based piece, and that limits its effectiveness.
We Are Marshall is precisely what one expects from a true sports story: it's uplifting and inspiring.
Stallone has said this is it for Rocky -- even if the film is major box office hit, there will be no seventh outing. If that's the case, it's hard to think of a better sendoff.

It might be fair to give Ben Stiller an 'A' for effort, but to call what he does in this movie "acting" is a misnomer. He does a lot of running around, occasionally falling down or bumping into things.
In order to propel circumstances to a conclusion, Notes on a Scandal relies upon a contrivance so ugly and obvious that it's impossible to ignore.
Although imperfect, it's engaging, thought-provoking stuff.
An achievement. Many films with 'split personalities' invest all their creative energy into one aspect of the story, causing the other one to founder and feel obligatory.
The love story is beautifully constructed. There's some sentimentality here, but [director Chris] Noonan is careful not to take it too far and to avoid overplaying the audience's emotional chords.
Perfume is a challenging motion picture, and one whose impressions are not easily shaken.
movie_title: Perfume: The Story of a Murderer (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Quote not available.
For those who see it, the movie has a chance to connect. Freedom Writers is superior to what film-goers typically expect from an early January release.

This movie is the worst kind of offender: it thinks its funny and clever, but it is neither. The filmmakers have mistaken banality for wit and silliness for humor, and that doesn't begin to address how visually clunky this motion picture is.
From past experience, viewers know that Cedric the Entertainer can be very funny. While there are times when Code Name: The Cleaner highlights his comedic abilities, there aren't enough of them.
O'Toole deserves all the praise he has been getting for this part.
Charlotte's Web has all the requisite elements that a family film needs to succeed and endure: humor, drama, pathos, and an emotionally satisfying ending.
Why has 20th Century Fox released this embarrassment - whose quality would be dubious for a direct-to-video release - into theaters?
After the action shifts from the deserts of the Middle East to the relative calm of the home front (specifically, Spokane, Washington), it devolves into a morass of melodramatic clichés.
Welcome to the new world of MI6's most storied agent.

Déjà Vu impresses with both the complexity of its storyline and its willingness to allow things to develop at their own pace without interjecting a lot of needless action scenes into the early proceedings to keep viewers attentive.
