movie_title: Tenacious D in The Pick of Destiny (2006)

movie_review_blurb: I love the Christmas season, but there are times when I wish it would go away if only to save audiences from horrific experiences like this.

For those who are not pulled to this movie for its religious slant, there's no reason to go. There's nothing here for a serious movie-goer. Despite the sizeable budget, this is little more than a glossy Christmas tract.
Ten Items or Less is not landmark cinema nor is it deeply thought-provoking, but it's smart, funny, knowledgeable about life and people, and a crowd-pleaser.
What a croc! Unsolicited advice to filmmakers: When making a monster movie, do not attempt to sell said film as a picture about a serial killer.
Turistas starts out as an effective little horror movie before devolving into an incoherent mess during its final 30 minutes.
Sloppy writing, an overindulgent editor, and poor casting have taken an intriguing premise and transformed it into an uneven mess.
Perhaps the kindest way to describe Anthony Minghella's Breaking and Entering is to say it's evident as being broken fairly early during the proceedings.

If only Edward Zwick's mastery of the medium had extended to pruning the screenplay and editing the final result, Blood Diamond might have been a tremendous film rather than one worthy of only a lukewarm recommendation.
It's unlike any other movie to reach theaters this year and, because it is as visual an experience as it is visceral, it is best seen on a large screen.
Dreamgirls is a wonderful entertainment: a musical that, while not skimping on the music, delivers a multi-layered storyline featuring complex characters.

The Good German, Steven Soderbergh's film noir homage, is nearly perfect when it comes to style and tone, but it concentrates so single-mindedly on the mechanics of the narrative that it loses sight of its characters.
How is it that movies 'inspired by a real story' often feel more fake than those fully embedded in the realm of fiction?
The story's lack of freshness is partially counterbalanced by solid acting and effective character development but, in the end, Off the Black fails to leave an impact.
Take away the blood and gore, however, and there's nothing left.
On inherent merit, the movie would not warrant such a highly publicized re-release, but this is one of those films that transcends what's on the screen.
The characters undergo nothing that could be remotely associated with development, the mystery is wafer-thin, and the slight plot is stretched to the breaking point in order to fill out 95 minutes.
A serviceable gore-minded thriller --- a competent execution of a premise that ultimately becomes hampered by its inherent constraints.
It's the kind of motion picture that's crying out to be featured on an episode of Mystery Science Theater 3000.
movie_title: Love in the Time of Cholera (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Unfortunately, Baumbach's follow-up to The Squid and the Whale, the pretentious and talky Margot at the Wedding, is more likely to contract than expand his appeal.
Regardless of the medium, this is an effectively brutal story of swords, sorcery, demons, and heroes, with an Oedipal hint or two thrown in for flavor.
The film is built not upon characters and plot but upon ideas. That would be fine if the ideas were revolutionary or interesting, but they're fairly commonplace.
An aggressively bad movie. There are times when it tips the scales of absurdity and becomes almost comical.
Dark, tense, and punctuated by just enough gore to keep the viewer's flinch reflex intact.
Enchanted earns its label as a "family film" by virtue of its ability to captivate audience members both young and old.
A gentle, unhurried drama about how people can connect with each other through conversation, nonverbal gestures, and writing.
These are fascinating, three-dimensional individuals brought into the foreground by a pair of today's finest actors.
The way characters interact with each other and the manner in which the master plan unfolds will stretch the credulity of even the most generous viewer.
Writer/director Chris Weitz brings a style that is more obligatory than deft. Constrained by a rushed feel and too little character development, this movie never seems to flow quite right.
This is a special motion picture that achieves its higher agenda of doing much more than idly plucking at a few heartstrings.
movie_title: The Diving Bell and the Butterfly (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Juno, directed by Jason Reitman, is smart, witty, and engaging -- three ingredients that, when applied to any film, comprise a recipe for success.

The film is gorgeous to look at, well paced (especially during the first half), and by turns touching and sad. The ending packs an emotional punch, which is what one would expect from any movie developed from a McEwan novel.
The film's multitude of flaws might be more easily forgiven if the movie didn't overstay its welcome by at least a half-hour.

The Coens know how a thing or two about pacing, and it's relentless here. The story is full of unexpected twists and switchbacks, and opportunities for the audience to gear down and take a breath are few and far between.
Martian Child wants to make us cry. It nearly made me gag. This is an exercise in shameless and inept emotional manipulation.
On the whole, this is another disappointing animated effort and it resides considerably lower on the totem pole than this year's current non-live action champion, Ratatouille.
If you have to see one penguin movie, this is it.
With respect to costumes and set design, this is a sumptuous affair. The script is less even, as is the pacing.
Sports movies have become so generic and so common that it takes something unusual or affecting to spark an audience. The Final Season has neither.
As cop/crime dramas go, this one offers little that's new but it takes the time to develop the characters and that's where its strengths lie.

Story-wise, this picture doesn't break new ground; this is a tale that one can find littered throughout the pages of history both recent and long ago, but the way Corbijn has presented it gives it a freshness and fervor that makes it worth sampling.
It's an interesting failure -- a film that works more successfully as a study of technique and writing than as a motion picture.
We are ambushed by a simplistic storyline that's more interested in sermonizing and demonizing than existing in the real world where things aren't as clear-cut as the movie would like us to believe.
If Martian Child is the price film goers must pay in order to get Grace Is Gone, then it's a worthwhile trade.
A flawed presentation of compelling material and intriguing characters.
The strength of the film's subject matter and the intelligence and perceptiveness with which it is approached make this not merely an October diversion but a genuine Oscar contender.
If this is the kind of movie you're looking for, it delivers.
It is neither as clever nor as funny nor as inventive as the daring title might lead one to expect.

This is not classic Sidney Lumet, but it's ample evidence that after more than 40 years working in this business, the director is still capable of crafting an entertaining and thought provoking motion picture.
movie_title: Before the Devil Knows You're Dead (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Beneath its aw-shucks, wants-to-be-liked exterior, this is a bankrupt motion picture. It's cloying, artificial, and not the least bit romantic.
Easily the worst and most pointless episode of the gore-saturated quadrology.
Washington rules the screen. His portrayal is one of many things that elevates this film to the level of being consistently entertaining and occasionally compelling.
Things We Lost in the Fire deals frankly and openly with the wounds -- some obvious, some not so obvious -- that are left by the tragic, untimely loss of a loved one. At times, the film is unsparing.
movie_title: Things We Lost in the Fire (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Successfully recaptures the feeling of what made the Apollo missions so special.
movie_title: In the Shadow of the Moon (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Revolver turns out to be worse than Swept Away -- and not just by a little bit.
At times brutal, at times touching, the movie stands out as one of the better 'prestige' productions offered for cinematic consumption during the waning weeks of 2007.

Mad Money is a comedy caper where the caper's not interesting and the comedy's not funny. Take away those elements and all that's left is a tepid female buddy movie and, like its male counterparts, we've had enough of those to choke a critic.

Untraceable engenders a reaction that is one part fascination, one part disappointment, and two parts frustration.
This is the first memorable movie of 2008.
It's a middling movie both in terms of the franchise and in terms of action movies in general.
While not horrifically bad, it's as mediocre a motion picture as you're likely to find in a multiplex this season.

It's refreshing for a romantic comedy not to follow the formula by rote. I only wish I could be as enthusiastic about the amount of screen time accorded to certain characters who are more tedious than endearing.
When it comes to showing something to end the second-rate horror drought, The Eye is blind.

Once the shooting starts, everything collapses, and the ending is the kind that causes head-shaking. It's as if the filmmaker realized he wrote himself into a corner and had to resort to a contrivance to bring things to a close.
For all its problems, though, The Hottie & the Nottie provides a valuable service. It reminds us that no matter how bad a one-star movie might be, it could always be worse. This is worse.

Brooks' take on the ups and downs of modern romance and the unexpected turns it takes is smart, funny, and (above all) uncommon.

There's enough here to keep adults engaged, which is an important component of any motion picture that wants to be known as 'family entertainment.' I would place The Spiderwick Chronicles comfortably in that category.

Catnaps are an advisable way to survive some of the slow spots. Or, better yet, wait for this to be available on DVD when the fast forward button will turn Step Up 2 into something shorter and more enjoyable.
This film takes you into the heart of the maelstrom and leaves you there.
27 Dresses is an illustration of what can result when the filmmakers possess a solid understanding of the romantic comedy formula and decide never to stray from it by one iota.

movie_review_blurb: With its rapid pace, smart screenplay, and top-notch acting, this is one of the 2007 Oscar season's most appealing and compelling adult motion pictures.

This is one of the better movies in recent years to address issues of racial inequality and the way in which individuals overcome them.
Frank Capra would have been at home here.
Smith nails the portrayal. It's not the kind of work that will earn him an Oscar nomination but audiences usually don't see better than this in genre films.

An effective mixture of horror and fantasy, with the supernatural bleeding into dreams that teeter on the brink of reality.

movie_review_blurb: Cashback is light, smart, and enjoyable, and it makes me eager to see what Ellis has planned for his next outing.
It's not exactly revolutionary territory but it is effectively presented and it will be hard to find viewers who aren't at least a little moved by what director Scott Hicks has placed on the screen.

While nothing in this motion picture quite matches the television series at its early best, this is more of a throwback than a throw-away. It's wittier and more energetic than anything that has appeared on FOX in quite a few years.
Easily marks the worst movie Lohan has appeared in and the worst performance she has given.

When it comes to action, The Bourne Ultimatum trumps the summer's other offerings. While its stunts are no less preposterous than those in Live Free or Die Hard, what The Bourne Ultimatum offers is grittier and more visceral.
Unfortunately, lead actress Anne Hathaway is not suited to the role. Her Jane doesn't seem like the main character in her own story.
Interview has its moments but they can't prevent it from feeling a little long winded and unsatisfying. The premise makes it sound more interesting than the in-theater experience delivers.
This is one of those films where the humor is of the hit-and-miss variety, and it misses more often than it hits. The jokes are transparent. It's not difficult to divine what's supposed to be funny.

It's uncomfortable to take a negative stance against something that is so plainly a labor of love. But the sad truth is that the movie doesn't offer enough to make it interesting or even diverting.

The movie is uneven in the extreme, to the extent that it feels like two imperfectly wed pictures. The first, while not extraordinary, at least contains some interesting ideas. The second borders on embarrassing.
Hairspray exceeded my expectations and, while it isn't my favorite movie of the pool-and-beach season, it's enjoyable enough to earn a recommendation.
Rarely have I found myself so uncomfortable viewing anything over such an extended period of time. There's nothing redeemable here. It's not tense or scary; it's just demented.

It gives us a few interesting characters and allows us to follow them through a critical phase of change and growth. It does what all good coming of age movies do, and that makes it a worthy and welcome entry into the genre.

For non comic book fans over the age of 13, Fantastic Four: Rise of the Silver Surfer is a tedious, incoherent bore. For comic book fans of any age, it is an atrocity.

movie_review_blurb: It becomes increasingly difficult to care one way or another about characters who act like they have undergone frontal lobotomies.
While I admit that Evan Almighty isn't as ineptly constructed and poorly realized as its predecessor, this still isn't a wise investment of anyone's entertainment dollar.
Casavetes tells her tale, but it's one we've already seen, and she doesn't bring much that's new or fresh to the narrative.
Whatever anyone's feelings may be about Michael Moore, it's hard to disagree with his argument that health care in the United States is broken and needs to be fixed.

The strength of the screenplay and acting provide a satisfying, although not overwhelming, two hours of romance, drama, and tragedy.

Live Free or Die Hard may work better for an audience that doesn't know much about the series than it will for Die Hard die hards, who will be wondering who that impersonator is and what he did with the real John McClane.
For Transformers fans, I suppose this is a dream motion picture. For everyone else, it's a nightmare.
No matter how hard I try, I'm finding it difficult to write anything positive about License to Wed. This movie is bad from top to bottom, front to back, and start to finish.

With its fifth cinematic outing, the Harry Potter film series has ascended to another level.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Haunting and disturbing, Time is the kind of motion picture that gets under your skin and doesn't let go. It lingers long after the final credits have rolled and, for those who see it with friends, it will provoke endless post-movie discussions.
For parents looking to spend time in a theater with their kids or adults who want something lighter and less testosterone-oriented than the usual summer fare, Ratatouille offers a savory main course.
The movie is frequently amusing and occasionally uproarious.
The problem with most werewolf movies isn't that they're derivative, but that they're badly written, badly acted, or just plain silly. Skinwalkers hits the trifecta: all three apply.
This Is England may be set in 1983 but it's as relevant today as it was then.
One could make an argument that, among 20th century directors, few were more versatile than Billy Wilder.
It's a perfect example of how awful direction and performances can ruin an adequate screenplay.

Unfortunately, first-time director Mike Cahill spends an inordinate amount of time dealing with the nuances of the hunt and caper and, even with his attempts to add in a dash of comedy, he can't redeem this aspect of the project.
By the end of the movie, I don't know that I liked Chris, but I understood him and sympathized with him, and sometimes that's more important.
The Jane Austen Book Club is an example of how a movie can follow the general plot of a book yet fail to capture the spirit.
The final screenplay is as devoid of real emotion as it is of real characters.
Parts of the movie are brilliant in a Terrence Malick-inspired way, but the lugubrious middle section is badly in need of the hand of a ruthless editor.
movie_title: The Assassination of Jesse James by the Coward Robert Ford (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Good acting would not have served the material well, since it would have diluted the comedy quotient and made the campy elements seem cheap and cheesy.
There is nothing dated about The Exorcist, which remains an effective excursion into demonic possession more than a quarter of a century after it was first unveiled to the public.

The movie is filmed in a way that makes it seem like the camera has epilepsy and the color desaturation renders everything murky. Someone should remind director Marcus Nispel that there's a difference between making a music video and a feature film.
The film is smart and engaging, and if it plays a little on our fears of the next big terrorist attack, it does so without feeling exploitative.
Aided by the nuanced, forceful performances of his two leads, [Ang Lee] has made Lust, Caution something to be seen and savored.

It's a celebration of cultural diversity and an affirmation that, despite differences in race, religion, and societal norms, people are essentially the same, with a lack of understanding being a key block to better relations.
The screenplay combines philosophy, melodrama, and clichés to engaging effect.
A straightforward and uninspired look at the sex trade.
One could never argue that Across the Universe isn't ambitious. However, like many ambitious movies, this one fails spectacularly.
Perhaps the director set the bar so high with A History of Violence that there was no way he could equal it with Eastern Promises, but for him to fall so far short is nothing less than criminal.
The last scene of In the Valley of Elah may be the most ridiculously ham-fisted and over-the-top moment in all of 2007's supposed prestige cinema.
Drinking the full adrenaline-with-a-wink cocktail might be too much, but there's nothing wrong with sampling it.
The mismatched blending of Hirschbiegel's low-key horror and the Wachowski Brothers' anything-but-low-key action sequences results in a cinematic dud.
Firth is horribly miscast. I'll buy him as a romantic lead or the main character in a drama, but he's almost laughable as an action hero.
Hawke has made this movie his way and the result is a story that is by turns romantic and disquieting.

The old Mr. Bean was a lot funnier than this one. It's a combination of things: lackluster writing (neither Richard Curtis nor Mel Smith returned this time), a lack of energy, and curiously poor timing for some of the jokes.
Although it is bloody and at times brutal, it doesn't revel in the violence. There's more to the movie than initially meets the eye for an eye.
There's real heart to be found in the story but it comes along with borderline saccharine sentimentality, a too facile ending, and clean outcomes that aren't earned.

This isn't great cinema, but it adequately fills a niche. Those who like their action loud and bloody won't be disappointed. There's a high body count and lots of explosions and, for some, that's what this is all about.
While this is admittedly not lighthearted mainstream fare, the subject matter is interesting and is handled in a manner that offers a compelling and sometimes unsettling 95 minutes.
Freshman Orientation feels a bit like a missed opportunity. It's too bad the motion picture as a whole isn't as quirky and clever as its double-edged title.
Although it's not saying much, this is director Rob Zombie's most impressive outing behind the camera.
Deep Water is a documentary, but it's also one part adventure film, one part Greek tragedy, and one part meditation on the role of the 'hero' in modern society.
The result is such a mish-mash of conflicting tones and ideas that it doesn't play well on any level.
Watching a movie like this, I can't help but wish that the Western would come back into favor again. We can use more productions like this.
Overall, it's an enjoyable effort, but not a positive triumph.
Romance and Cigarettes is good, not-so-clean fun.
This is the sort of ho-hum production that will likely seem less disappointing on a smaller screen.
An intensely personal, psychological tale, and one which highlights survival as much as massacre.
Shot simply but compellingly, it feels like a polished and practised portrait of rekindled bonds.
It all feels as though a dash of the surreal has been woven into moments of banal human experience to see how far reality bends before it snaps.
It's worth the price of admission to see Norton and De Niro sparring across a prison-house desk.
This is a smart, well-built documentary that does greatly deepen the account of Spitzer's fall from grace, as advertised.
movie_title: Client 9: The Rise and Fall of Eliot Spitzer (2010)

movie_review_blurb: An undeniably courageous effort to document the inward defiance smouldering in many behind a veneer of submission.
The film's biggest problem, though, is that it spends so much time in a vacuous Hollywood demimonde that some of the emptiness inevitably rubs off.
